Every one things working on the line is easy, but the only thing that sucks about the line is you can't leave and you have to put up with customers that want 20 burritos all different. I worked there for 5 months and I was always on prep, marinating chicken. Overall its not as fun as it seems, but you'll find really cool chill people to work with and that makes it kinda better.
Advice to Management: Somethings I thought having more than one boss was great but they never worked with each they were all on different pages and unorganized.

Title: "Okay place to work for HS students"
Pros:
fun atmosphere
free food
endless soda
made friends with some staff members
Cons:
cleaning at night sucks
some staffers are mean
Advice to Management: bring in a night shift to clean the kitchen

Title: "Fast-paced environment, with great employees."
Pros: Great workers and really care for their employees. Great pay ($9/hr starting pay, but most employees I met got at least one raise within their first 3 months). Everyone is very passionate about the food and truly believe in the food with integrity. Everyone is very motivating and they are all about praising everyone for their good work. The employee discounts and benefits are excellent.
Cons: Very fast-paced. They expect a lot from their employees. Training was very fast, and was actually put to work before I was trained and even went to orientation. By my 3rd day, they had me on the line without a trainer. Expect you to learn all of their definitions they give you within your first 2 days. I worked there for 3 days and ended up quitting because they had me scheduled for more hours than my maximum hours listed, and expected very much of me. On 2 of the days I worked there I was held over 2 hours after my shift ended each day.
Advice to Management: Train employees a little more before you put them out to work. Hire more employees (we were very understaffed). Don't go over peoples maximum hours they can work. Keep people on track with their hours and don't hold them over their shift as often.

Title: "Best job I've ever had"
Pros:
Encouraged to move up and be better by not only management but coworkers also
Fun and positive work place
Everyone is friends and helps eachother
Cons: Very fast paced, hard to keep up

Title: "Fast-paced,"
Pros:
Higher level of skill demanded from employee
Real kitchen skills taught
Dedicated team of workers
Great company values (sustainability and food with integrity) talked about regularly
Good culture of people aiming to succeed
Cons:
Long hours with difficult shifts (most of the time not a good balance with outside life)
High demand on each employee
Difficulty to achieve promotion
Very high standards
Advice to Management: Training could be done in a much better way (at least at the where store I worked. Most new employees are completely overwhelmed within the first day.

Title: "The worst job I've had yet"
Pros:
I met a few really awesome people who were my trainers and co-workers.
The free food was nice.
I met some great customers who I will miss.
Cons:
Really bad managment at my store.
They did not care about the well being of their employees (made me work while throwing up).
LONG hours. I sometimes would work split shifts that only allowed me one meal a day.
Hardly got a chance to go to the bathroom or drink water.
Standing on my feet for nine hours.
DRAMA like crazy between the crew members (this obviously would vary by location).
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees. Especially if they are ill. A lot of support and encouragement is what makes us feel empowered. Not being ignored and treated like cattle that can be replaced. I would have stayed with the company for years if it weren't for my managers.

Title: "A very fast passed environment where you are constantly challenged and expected to have high standards"
Pros: Constantly working, little down time, always something new to learn.
Cons: Very demanding while you are working. Hardly any downtime. You'll know you worked a shift at Chipotle when you're done!

Title: "Great Work While in school"
Pros: Free meals and friendly environment
Cons: manual labor can be exhausting at times

Title: "The company is friendly, and they care about their employees."
Pros:
Free food on the clock and 50% when not working.
Perfect for college student.
Flexible hours
Cons:
Stressful
Not enough money for the amount of work
Advice to Management: N/A

Title: "(Great company, horrible region."
Pros: Great mission, great standards, the CEOs are extremely personable, and have great business plans laid out for the future
Cons: The GLE is the worst management I have ever seen
Advice to Management: Stop ruining the Chipotle vision

Title: "Weird Company to work for"
Pros: Free food and pay is above state min.
Cons: You don't get to leave on time, you don't get a break if you don't finish everything that needs to get done and management plays favorites.

Title: "Amazing people work here but the job is underpaid."
Pros: The people that work here are very nice
Cons:
Managers and people that visit throw everything off
A slight mistake can cause the whole day to collapse

Title: "Worked within a family environment"
Pros: Flexible hours. Worker benefits. Free meals
Cons: Rotation of assignments. Really wanted to work in other stations

Title: "Good job for a college student"
Pros: everyone is young so easy to make friends if you are also, free meals on breaks, 50% off otherwise, if you're lucky you'll have a manger who actually cares about you
Cons: hard work, long hours, don't get paid after 12:30 am, bad/unorganized management, some managers won't help you out even if you're in dire need of help, customers can be very rude and many make special requests which can be annoying
Advice to Management: Really connect with your people and don't play favorites. Do one on ones and have manager meetings when it's not busy. Lead by example and don't be a hypocrite

Title: "Working at Chipotle involved a lot of overtime, fast paced work, but over all a satisfying experience."
Pros: Pros included the tight knit crew and always having a good time with coworkers, as well as a free meal every day worked.
Cons: Cons included somewhat shuffled management. They had goals to advance the store but lacked the organization and general discipline to do so.
Advice to Management: I suggest scheduling employees more realistic hours. If the schedule says 9 to 2, I expect to get out relatively close to 2. Waiting to tell me I have to stay two more hours until the last minute does not make happy employees. Also, work on your favorites. I know everyone is friendly, but when you would bestow the best hours on certain people it really strikes hard.

Title: "It's a great place to work"
Pros: free food when working, 50% off when not working, paid more than minimum wage, free shirt and hat to work in,
Cons: Expect a lot for just being a fast food place.
Advice to Management: come out on the line whenever you see that we are crazy busy

Title: "Chip"
Pros: Great work atmosphere, crew is one of the best I've ever worked with, managers are also some of the best I've worked with.
Cons: Stressful at times due to the demand requested of all crew members. Can feel unrewarding sometimes due to customers or circumstances.

Title: "An amazing company and culture!"
Pros: The culture here is amazing. I've worked for many well-respected Fortune 500 companies, and I am still so impressed by Chipotle every day. People here really truly care about making those around them better. We work hard, but also play hard and it feels like family. For the most part, everyone really walks the talk. In addition, the Food With Integrity mission is literally changing the world. I am shocked that I still haven't gotten sick of the food, and still continue to learn new things every day.
Cons: Because everyone gets along so well and it doesn't feel like work, sometimes work can really bleed into personal life, so this is not for everyone. In addition, there are always a few people that do not fit the culture, but at the regional leadership level, it can be slow to remove those people from the team, which does not fit with what we preach at the restaurant level.
Advice to Management: Make sure those in support staff roles, the national teams and senior regional leadership also fit the culture and are empowering their teams. It's not enough to tell people how to inspire others without doing it yourself. Sometimes, we do not hold the leadership team accountable they same way we do the restaurant teams.

Title: "Horrible treatment and overworking of new workers"
Pros: High pay, free food, decent looking uniform.
Cons: The management is a mess and all they care about is becoming restaurateur and will abuse and lie to staff to get to that position. They lied about pay along with lying about what i would be doing. overall a horrible experience Horrible hours as well.
Advice to Management: train your people better.

Title: "Hard work but well rewarding"
Pros: Pay well, constantly moving and will never be bored or have to sit around doing nothing
Cons: Can be overwhelming, many customers are rude when serving food.
Advice to Management: Have better training for beginners.

Title: "Although I am busy at work, I enjoy my time working there due to the fun environment."
Pros:
The office culture is fun and helpful.
Employee meals are always delicious.
Management cares about employees.
Cons: The training process was too long and redundant.
Advice to Management: Management overall is great. One change would be allow workers to make there own work schedules.

Title: "Good BUT not Great!"
Pros: Best reasons to work for Chipotle was being able to learn how to work with Customers in a fast-paced environment. I gained many great friends not just employers!
Cons: Leadership was not clear, too many people thought they were in-charge. Schedule and paper work was not organized.
Advice to Management: More one on one sit downs with each employees. Keep on achieving the High Standards.

Title: "Ehhh"
Pros: Good experience to help you learn how to multitask
Cons: Most of the workers are bitter, washed up people who are really negative and hard to deal with behind the scenes
Advice to Management: Hire younger and more upbeat personalities who don't cry and complain every five minutes

Title: "Too much for the pay."
Pros: Free employee meal & 50% off at your store
Cons: way too much work for the pay. Constant organized chaos almost every shift, really bad turnover rate.
Advice to Management: Stop excessively micro mana

Title: "Friendly Environment"
Pros: This is a friendly environment but it is also hard work. Chipotle has a family based environment.
Cons: Because there aren't a lot of people usually working at one store your work/life balance isn't well balanced. Also if you are closing be prepared to stay at least and hour and a half after closing.
Advice to Management: I really don't have any advice to upper management. Upper management in the store don't treat you are just a worker but more than that.

Title: "not bad"
Pros: Good to balance with school
Cons: The pay could be better given the hours
Advice to Management: teach workers how to roll burrito.

Title: "Cew"
Pros: Up beat work flow. Get to meet great people. Opportunity to move up.
Cons: Can overwork you at times. Can get a bit stressful.

Title: "IT RSS"
Pros: Great Company and work environment
Cons: Limited growth in non restaurant operation positions

Title: "Chipotle"
Pros: Good pay, loving staff, quick promoting
Cons: long hours, high expectation without proper training

Title: "Great work, if it's with the right people"
Pros: Great people, really great company. Takes care of its workers.
Cons: On your feet all day, often hot, sweaty work

Title: "Good"
Pros: I liked it it was fun
Cons: Long hours customers suck sometimes
Advice to Management: Better scheduling

Title: "It was an interesting developing experience, but there was a moment where they stopped training me to do more."
Pros: You can move up from crew member into management pretty quick. You are trained in different areas.
Cons:
Depending on management the store does not flow smoothly.
Sometimes your crew does not want to train you properly because they want to do better than you.
Advice to Management: My advice would be to be strict on the managers as well and not just the crew because sometimes management really slacks off and do not care because they feel untouchable.

Title: "Lots of work."
Pros: Good comradery; fun, close-knit crew. The managers actually seem to care about you and your life. You get out what you put in.
Cons: The company really expects you to give them your all, and then some. If you don't live up to their standards, then you can't cut it.
Advice to Management: Maybe try to minimize the turnover. If you kept a solid staff, and gave them good hours, they will stay. But it seems though you'd rather give everyone minimal hours a week, and keep a huge staff.

Title: "Amazing experience working here"
Pros: The skills and experience earned.
Cons: The long hours and customers

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: Engaging environment, excellent growth opportunities, generous benefits
Cons: Locations without the right amount of employees can lack high standard operations and service
Advice to Management: Maintain the right amount of employees so that they aren't overworked and customers get the best experience.

Title: "A huge learning experience in food, people, and being a leader."
Pros:
Learn how to prep food, grill, working the line, and being a cashier all at one place.

Bring out the best in yourself and others

Learn how to talk to people in an outside of your company.
Cons:
They try to be competitive with pay, but really only offer 1.50 more than min wage in any given area to start.
Expected to have a high level of commitment to the job
Once you get promoted, the raise doesn't get substantial until you are one under the general manager.
Advice to Management: There are many people working for you that don't have the 13 characterics, so they don't want to get rid of people that don't have them either. The city stores are riddled with low performers. If you want to move up in the company though, pretty much anyone can do it.

Title: "Rewarded by making the people around you better"
Pros: Growth opportunities great people culture great food culture
Cons: Busy environment customers in some areas are very demanding and rude but like I said it depends on the area

Title: "Terrible place to work, management had no idea what they were doing, blatant favoritism all around."
Pros: Free meal on your break
Cons:
Shifts from 3-11 pm, break given to employees from 3:05-3:35.
Management had no business sense whatsoever.
Crew fired and replaced every 6 months, leading to forced overtime or termination.
Blatant favoritism, shifts tailored to favorite employees.
Advice to Management:
-Promoting from within does nothing when you only promote favorites.

-Rather than fire anyone who has an idea that you couldn't take credit for, or that made you look bad. Try "Empowering" your team, or even listening to the nonsense corporate terms you spew to justify your terrible management styles.

Title: "Play by their rules or you will be looking for another job. Not a job that will last you through college."
Pros:
Free Chipotle
Flexible Schedule
Hours if you earn them
Cons:
Way underpaid for the work
Uneven pay scale for employees
You WILL last under a year unless you plan on making it your career. If they want you out, they will find a reason.
There is no loyalty. Working hard doesn't mean anything unless you play their way.
Advice to Management: I had a very bad experience with a regional manager that ended up letting me go an a technicality. Unprofessionalism ran rampant amongst the leadership team that consisted of 5 people in their late teens, early 20s. Poorly run at the store level. Hire more experienced GMs that won't sit in their office and cry during shifts. I was told I wasn't an asset and let go. I found a management job within a couple months.

Title: "i'd love to work at chipotle beacause i enhance my performance and everybody would help you how you improve more"
Pros: because the crew,managers everyone is nice they treat you good everyone helping each other .
Cons: for me i think on prep because is a lot of things to do,making the meat dicing cutting
Advice to Management: continue to manage the good service, keep it up

Title: "I was a Financial Accountant for Chipotle for 3.5 years. In the beginning the atmosphere was fun and energetic."
Pros:
-The company is still in a strong growth stretch
-Offers bonuses at different levels depending on role
-Office employees get $100.00 per month in free food
-Office employees get $100.00 in Chipotle swag
-Benefits are good
-Sabbatical offered after 10 years
-Bi-annual company retreats
-Free chips and salsa every Thursday
Cons:
-The Columbus office is a regional, accounting center. The main office (HQ) is in Denver, CO so you feel a little bit like a red-headed step child. Plus there's often times when travel to Denver is necessary
-Pay is below average
-Very little upward mobility in the accounting center (unless you're willing/able to move to Denver)
-Management are very good at accounting...not so good at managing teams
-Pay is extremely low considering what is asked of the employees
-The only way to get an above average annual performance rating is to somehow manage to save the company millions of dollars. The review process is a joke (although that's common).
Advice to Management: The management team is extremely capable when it comes to accounting knowledge and practices. However, they lack extremely when it comes to developing employees...or even relating to employees in most cases

Title: "Hard work."
Pros: Free food, busy all the time.
Cons: Had to stay longer than scheduled

Title: "Management"
Pros: The people you work with are friendly and overall good people. They make the work place.
Cons: Management doesn't know what they are doing. They are demeaning towards their employees and there are no incentives to work harder. They work you until you burn out.
Advice to Management: Treat employees like human beings. Do not play favorites.

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: Wonderful work environment, employees care for one another.
Cons: Long hours standing and it can be hard to deal with disgruntled customers
Advice to Management: Encourage app use more.

Title: "I would definitely work here again"
Pros: Great company I loved it
Cons: Not enough hours for my lifestyle

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: Lots of hours, easy to pick up
Cons: Lots of hard work for little pay
Advice to Management: Not much

Title: "A very fast-paced, fun environment to work in and has a huge emphasis on helping employee's move up in the company."
Pros:
Great team work
Fast-paced
Free food
Great benefits
Decent pay
Extremely clean
Ability to learn a lot about culinary skills and efficiency
Fun environment
Amazing company culture
Cons:
The work can sometimes be hard on the body
Hours weren't ideal

Title: "Former line worker"
Pros: systemic outline of duties, overall easy
Cons: when slow, management typically send home extra help to save money.
Advice to Management: figure out a more lucrative setup

Title: "Top Performer = Most willing to work off the clock and/or go without break with no complaint."
Pros: No background check (parolees take note), friendly to immigrants, one free meal a day. Lateness is never punished.
Cons:
Staffing hours are limited by store sales (day/night sales from the previous week). For example, if you work at a 6k-a-day store you will be chronically short staffed. This creates pressure on workers to do more than their share of the work (and create enmity towards those who cannot do 1.5-2x their share). In addition, closers are automatically clocked out at 1230am. Then they are encouraged to "finish their work" after that time (without pay). "Getting your work done on time" (<11am day-shift, <1230am night shift) is the primary goal and will determine your longevity. During one-on-one's with management, the first question they will ask is, "How you feel you're doing?", the next will be, "Who do you think is not a top performer?" It's a constant witch hunt and it creates a toxic work environment.

If you call out (sick, funeral, car accident, weather), you have to find your own replacement.
Advice to Management: Push back against the labor management system built on sales. Stop "encouraging" crew members to work off the clock. Read about federal labor laws and abide by them.

Title: "There is a high emphasis on a sustainable culture of people development, providing great benefits and advancement."
Pros:
Great benefits
Fun work environment
Free meal every work day
%50 off when not working
Free uniforms and discounted swag
Insurance provided by employer
Cons:
Very high accountability
Lack of organized upper management
Corporate structure does not allow for creativity in the workplace
Uneven expectations
Advice to Management: Company is taking a turn from truly caring about its people to focusing on its business model. It is taking great strides in the food service industry, but needs to be careful that it doesn't fall into the same trap as every other restaurant that grows.

Title: "It really depends on who you're working with, but the company itself is worth working for"
Pros: great benefits, rewarding, fast-paced, high standards. really cares about the quality of food and its customers
Cons: customers can be difficult to work with, sometimes hard to get the hours you need

Title: "OK"
Pros:
Fun
easy to become manager
Cons:
overworked and underpaid
glass ceiling
Advice to Management: need more experienced managers

Title: "Previously employed as restaurant level management."
Pros:
Ability to advance
Can be fun
Fast paced work environment
Importance of having good people is stressed during hiring process
Cons:
The focus on cutting labor can make work environment stressful
Upper management is mostly concerned with finding restauranteur candidates and can ignore other management teams
Crew members are expendable
Life must become about Chipotle to be successful
Advice to Management: When you say that you care about the people, make sure that's true.

Title: "Dishonest no position was available manager ads are a bait and switch for a crew position"
Pros: Nothing besides good pay work load is high
Cons: Dishonest and lead you in a circle 6 interview over two months
Advice to Management: Be upfront at the beginning

Title: "Not enough pay because i got such little hours"
Pros: they gave free food and paid breaks.
Cons: They did not give enough hours.
Advice to Management: give your employees more hours because 7 hours is not enough.

Title: "Way too much to go through for $9 an hour."
Pros:
-Free food before or after work (if you're not closing)
-Discount when not working was decent (but only is at the location you work at)

That's about it. There was not a single thing that was good about working at this company.
Cons:
Well, I was excited to start working for this company, since they did put me through five interviews-- All of which I had to call and bother them to give me another one. They say they would call and never did. That should have been the warning sign that I should have just not have bothered to get a job at Chipotle.

-If you don't speak Spanish, good luck trying to get along with your co-workers.
-Given breaks way too early, not when really needed.
-Constantly ridiculed if you don't know the correct procedures and policies on your second day of training.
-Very hard to get into the cult-like group of people you work with.
-Not allowed to move during certain hours, even if you were just stepping foot away from your workplace to pick up something you saw fall.
-Managers don't care if they are biased in terms of race. It seemed to be everyone who was of Hispanic decent was favored over the people who weren't.
-No one cares if you have a personal life outside of work, they expect you to make Chipotle your life. You get called in on your days off, forced to stay past scheduled shift times, and yelled at if you even clock in a minute too early.

There is so much more I could say, but yeah. I was "let go" after only two weeks because I "didn't adhere or understand Chipotle's culture enough to appropriately live up to a top performers standards." I was there for two weeks. TWO. I was told by numerous co-workers that I was doing a great job and they thought I was a fast and reliable person. Honestly, they just hired like five new people before they fired me, and all of them were Hispanic, and I feel like I was discriminated against because I was white. I saw two other people get fired (during the whole two weeks working there) get fired, and both were white.
Advice to Management:
Consider letting the new employees, like myself, prove themselves before firing them after only two weeks. There was so much I wasn't even taught and I was gauged on how I preformed by just the little knowledge I did know.

To the CEO / Founder - Don't make it so difficult to get a job there, especially if you're only paying 25 cents above minimum wage. It isn't worth it to work so hard for so little money, and then just end up getting fired or our hours cut a few weeks later. Train your employees more thoroughly and maybe instead of deciding right away that they are "low performers" give them a probationary period of 90 days like most companies.

Title: "Kitchen Manager In Training"
Pros:
Great Hours (if you want them).
Great People/ Culture.
Amazing opportunities to move up. Every manager or almost all of them were crew once.
I've only been working here for 5 months and some change and I'm already in my second week of training to become a kitchen manager.
Cons:
To be entirely honest, it's a hard job. It requires a lot, and I mean a lot of sacrifice, and more importantly you have to be able to handle a lot of stress.
Cuts and bruises everywhere. Everything at this store is SHARP!
You don't get any time to breath. Although you get a 30-min paid break, while actually working you just have to keep going.
Advice to Management:
Undeniably Underpaid! The work crew members put in is insane for just a little bit more than minimum wage.
Management, specifically at my store, are out of control. No respect for employees, and constant drama.

Title: "Demanding, worthwhile... depending on location"
Pros: There is a lot of opportunity to move up. Ninety-Five percent of Chipotle management started out as a crew member.
Cons: The current management at your location may not be promoting a culture in which the promotion opportunities are well utilized, if at all.
Advice to Management: Focus on the people, not the numbers.

Title: "Don't believe the promises!"
Pros: I liked some of the team
Cons: The only thing of importance at this job is getting a task done. They talk about quality, yeah ok. Saw several practices that should have gotten them shut down. Especially from the upper management. If an employee is sick they should be sent home. Not made to stay because the manager has a day off and has plans. And if you did call in sick and didn't cover your own shift, you got fired. Huh?! Guess you can't be human. Several times saw the manager take money out of the safe to buy drugs. Yes, it actually happened. Then asked not to tell his boss about the shortage in the safe.
Advice to Management: I WILL NOT LIE OR MAKE PEOPLE SICK! You people need to look at the management before getting on people about the culture

Title: "Awesome Experience, Couldn't have asked for a better first job"
Pros: Free meals when you are working and 50% when you are not. Opportunity and opportunity. If you are looking for a job where you want to become a manager, Chipotle offers many many many opportunities for growth. Within my 2 years of working for the company I have seen over half of my co workers be promoted from crew members into management positions. The company offers raises every 6 months, holiday bonuses, paid vacation, 401k, and health benefits. Very flexible with hours, as a student, my managers worked with my schedule. I couldn't have asked for a better crew or managers that made me feel 100% appreciated and valued.
Cons: Shifts can be long and tiresome, handwork, but worth it!
Advice to Management: Keep up the amazing work.

Title: "Crew Member for Chipotle"
Pros: Great staff that are always happy and hard working. Expectations are high and it pushes you to work hard.
Cons: Understaffed and when rush hour hits, it is very hard to keep up with everything and being able to clock out on time.
Advice to Management: Hire more people during busy hours.

Title: "Seasonal Job"
Pros:
They train you on the job.
The workers are almost all college age and a fun group.
Cons: Because it is near several colleges, there can be high turnover. If you make any mistakes, they will kick you out because the job pool is large.

Title: "Horrible for a first job"
Pros: You can eat free Chipotle. Thr company had great values and stands for the best in fast food. Had changed fast food for the better
Cons: The training is almost nonexistent

Title: "No experience needed job where hard work and interpersonal skills will get you promoted quickly. Great food!"
Pros: Fast-paced, personal growth, good food, great culture
Cons: corporate jargon, hard work, stores are inconsistent with management

Title: "Chipotle made me hate my life"
Pros: Free employee meal, good to get experience working your butt off, dental benefits
Cons: You don't get paid NEARLY enough for how hard you work, too much focus on memorizing meaningless keywords so your restaurant can become "restaurateur", sexual harassment scandal at restaurant was not taken seriously and joked about by management after the investigation was over
Advice to Management: Pay your hourly employees more and stop picking favorites

Title: "CHIPOTLE is the place to be if you are someone who can feel empowered in the workplace, and on all ends!"
Pros:
From the meals, down to the whole infrastructure of how this company works, and treats its employees, Chipotle truly knows how to provide an exceedingly better experience each and every day.

They actually keep up on your progress and want, more than ever, for you to get better and better at what you do. Their whole company culture is based off of how much better you can make the person next to you. This fuels a great deal of motivation, empowerment, and refinement in each of the awesome processes that take place while you work. In fact, knowing that teaching and working your knowledge with somebody outside of yourself is one of the best ways to cement said knowledge, I find it to be very, very wise of them to do this. It has propelled me tenfold, within the short month and a half I have put in here, so far.

The next Pro on my list would definitely have to be the fact that everyone communicates efficiently. Having a team of Top Performers means that the crew will surely take after the example of the Management in the aspect of communication, and problem solving, which they actively engage in with the team on a daily basis, during our chip talks. They do a good job of empowering us through that communication, so we may make the same type of choices in wake of any problem.

The last one I will rant about is the food. I have been in love with this place since I was 14, and now I am even more in love, knowing how it all comes together, and what it takes to run at the efficiency we do on the daily. But aside from that, being able to take part in fresh whole food, with naturally raised chicken, and No-GMO's to slow me down, is the biggest bonus of all. I am fueled, and my body reacts accordingly during my shifts. I have noticed a vast improvement in my muscle function and my energy levels since starting here.. vast..

And if that isn't enough, here is a list of a few more reason I love my job!

- Family-like and friendly crew, upper management, and corporate employees, whom also care about your progress, and well-being.

-They work with your schedule always, as long as you truly have an arrangement that needs to be met.

-They pay more than most fast food places when hired on, by almost a dollar or so.

-They have hours to give due to the deployment requirements for the line.

-2 Meals per 6+ hour shift.

-Holiday parties/events

-Guilt-Free Employer

-They make an effort to source mostly organic, Non-GMO foods, when possible, from local farmers. This helps the farming and agriculture industry a great deal in terms of family owned farms, who need this kind of business to keep them going, and extend their methods for higher yields. This would create more fresh, whole-foods for more people.

:)
Cons: I have no complaints that are relevant to the happiness my job brings me. :)
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing, My Friends!

Title: "I have worked for this company for 11 years and it is going through growing pains."
Pros: The team that I was allowed to put together.
Cons: The field leaders do not inspire, teach, or coach.
Advice to Management: Connect with your people, like you require the restaurant management to do with their crew.

Title: "Cashier"
Pros: Fun coworkers, free meal, cool hats
Cons: poor management. The managers would not give out breaks until the very end of the shift and then blame it on the crew for being slow.
Advice to Management: Do your job and manage people and stop saying that it's the employees fault

Title: "Grill/prep"
Pros: People, managers are cool to work with
Cons: Pay is not great for all the work they want you to do
Advice to Management: Stop treating it like it's a 5 start restaurant. You make burritos. It's fast food.

Title: "Great place to work, but not an easy job"
Pros:
Good pay, excellent opportunities for advancement, free Chipotle and oftentimes free Starbucks or Donuts, great co-workers, lots of hours if you work hard, long breaks, health benefits.

Chipotle has strong values regarding people and food, if you believe in them, it is really empowering! Managers at all levels really care about the store and employees.
Cons: Difficult work, always busy, can be very exhausting

Title: "It's great most of the time, but there are times I want to quit."
Pros: It's a very friendly environment, with people who want to climb up the ladder. I also love the fact that we are so dedicated to food with integrity.
Cons: The work sometimes can be tiring, especially during peak hours. Some co-workers do not actually empower you to be better at what you do, but rather make jokes out of it.

Title: "Wouldn't go back"
Pros: You obviously can't beat a free meal every work day. There's a wide variety of jobs you can choose from.
Cons: Chipotle is a place where there's always something that can be fixed, and at first the management is gung ho about the new innovation that's been introduced. But rarely does it actually get implemented. The crew members are treated as though they are lower, and they're opinions are less relevant than upper management, whereas the managers are basically given carte blanche. The process to even begin advancement all depends on the manager as opposed to work ethic.
Advice to Management: Develop an evaluation process that anonymously involves everyone, some employees may be different when management is around as opposed to when its just crew.

Title: "Bad management in many stores."
Pros:
If you have a good manager, the crew would be like your family.
Health benefits
Cons:
Dealing with angry customers 70% of the day
Feels kind of like high school sometimes
Advice to Management: Always connect with your crew. Know what they like and what they don't like. Listen to them. A restaurant needs a manager in the front of the house, not hiding in the back.

Title: "Great Company To Work For"
Pros:
-Paid Break
-Advancement Within Company
-Free Meal on every Shift
Cons:
-Young Management is inexperienced
-Training lacks at some stores
Advice to Management: -Training Could be a lot better for employees and managers

Title: "working for chiptle is slowly but surely changing my life"
Pros: the opportunities that this company offers are amazing, ive never worked for anybody or seen anybody who has unlimited opportunities and actually act on what they say.
Cons: moving up, learning some of the stations at a timely fashion.
Advice to Management: better evalluate the managers that you promote

Title: "Na"
Pros: like the job good people
Cons: one in line cooking on the grill washing dishes and preparing food
Advice to Management: Na

Title: "Bells and Whistles behind Pipe dreams"
Pros: When I started working for Chipotle I was starting at a brand new store with a brand new staff. The time and money dedicated to training us shows how much the company cares about the "Chipotle Experience".
Cons: Not every manager is on the same page. Some may allow 30 min breaks whereas others make 10 minutes mandatory.
Advice to Management: Break policy needs to be clear across the boards.

Title: "The crew is the best!"
Pros: The thing that kept me going to this place was the friendliness of the crew and the KM. Learning new things was cool and even without the GM or SM we were able to run things, I was left in charge of the restaurant when the only manager had to step out to make a deposit at the bank. You definitely learn how to become a leader.
Cons: The higher ups are a pain to work with, all they are focused on is getting a higher positions without caring who they hurt in the process. It was horrible having to see the KM and my fellow crew be overworked and under appreciated. The higher ups never want to do any work even when short handed and limit to just say, "hurry up" or "We're leaving at 10"
Advice to Management: Get to know your crew better, they really want you to succeed, but you have to be kind and listen to their needs.

Title: "A lot of work, not enough pay"
Pros: It allows you to gain a lot of leadership and time management skills.
Cons: Management is extremely annoying. They are always on you about the different tasks that you have throughout the day. Training did not help with the actual work.
Advice to Management: Do a more thorough training session.

Title: "AVOID AT ALL COSTS"
Pros: Free food, discounts, no drug test
Cons: Sexual harrasment, no job stability, they HATE college students
Advice to Management: Please stop allowing your general manager to sexually harass your employees and allowing him to fire them whenever he feels like it.

Title: "Good first job"
Pros: half off meals, Taco Tuesday/Thursday BUSY DAYS! Fun fast work.
Cons: If it's slow and shift leader/manager don't like you you'll be sent home early. As early as 2 HRS!

Title: "I would consider going back in the future"
Pros: Good atmosphere, pays a little above minimum wage, management really tried to have us all work as a team, managers were typically attentive, occasional one-on-ones with managers to get your perspective on how things are running, and when people came in for job interviews the crew members had a chance to speak with them and give their boss their own opinions
Cons: Horrible customers, hard to get time off, we ran out of necessities regularly (as in we ran out of chips, bags, portion cups, etc), grossly unqualified employees getting promoted, very fast-paced, everything is your job (cooking, serving, cleaning, all at once)

Title: "Chipotle"
Pros: Free employee meal. Half off meal when not on the clock. If you work extremely hard you can be a manager.
Cons: Pay is not enough for all the work asked of you. Zero to little training is offered.
Advice to Management: Learn how to train people better. Teach portion management! Charge for extra items. 6 tortillas on the side should not be free

Title: "This particular restaurant was awful but most Chipotles are a great opportunity."
Pros: Great environment, promotions are easy to come by
Cons: Had to stay after hours often, crew was awful, some managers didn't care
Advice to Management: Clean house at the Troy, MI location

Title: "Fun"
Pros: It was nice working as many hours as I want
Cons: Hard work and not enough money
Advice to Management: Good Job

Title: "Great Company, Bad Workers"
Pros: Paid Breaks, Chipotle has a great Reputation
Cons: Co-Workers are evil and unprofessional Chipotle feels like high school everyone is petite and childish.
Advice to Management: Nothing

Title: "Overall, a great company to work for and the ability to move up quickly."
Pros: Great culture and environment to work in, the company really values each of their employees, and they are flexible with your life schedule.
Cons: Being able to work on your feet, need to work for your promotions, ability for personal growth if you can show your ability to move up.

Title: "If you would like to train millennials and do their work at the same time for 20K per year under market, go for it."
Pros: Food card if you can tolerate the food.
Cons: You have to be all about Chipotle. Little promotions going on at the HQ location other than they call it a "promotion" with no increase in salary. If you are well educated and have a start on your career already or this might be your first job, stay away from Chipotle. There is no advantage to your career.
Advice to Management: I would say, start thinking about individuals who are educated and working at HQ from a career growth perspective. Obviously, the company is an operational in nature, however, very tough to keep folks at HQ Wynkoop if you don't open up opportunities for these individuals as well and "pay them market". Yes, we like to get payed market or above as well ( doh ).

Title: "Good for what it is if you can keep up"
Pros: Pay is very decent for entry level position and they encourage people to move up in the company. You can maintain a regular schedule and just grind it out.
Cons: They will expect you to earn every cent of your paycheck and there is a lot of work involved. If you have a decent work ethic this isnt so bad.

Title: "Decent fast food gig - free meal every shift"
Pros: Great food, prepared fresh daily. It was the freshest fast food I've ever made. Pays higher than the average fast food gig, and they make sure to feed you every day. As a single mom and college student - I really appreciated that they worked around my school/life schedule. I worked with great people.
Cons: Expected too much work in too little time. I would have been happier to do it, and would have done it longer had they paid more.

Title: "It was a good experience but management needs to be trained a bit better"
Pros: Most of the tasks were easy to complete. The people are great to work with. Not to mention free meals.
Cons: Worked mostly closing shifts so my advice would be to move the shifts around so people have experience with everything.

Title: "Incompetence immaturity and ignorance all rolled up into a high calorie over-priced burrito"
Pros: The cool loud music
Cons: Managers were idiots. I had 10+ years on both. "Pranked" me by convincing me I had stolen $ from the register. They thought it was HILARIOUS.
Advice to Management: I don't think 21 year olds have the mental capacity to run their own stores.

Title: "You have to love people."
Pros: Great environment, fast paced, good values, good pay considering it is fat food, chances for promotions. Free meals and 50% off for family.
Cons: Customers can really make the job hard. Do not work here if you are a people's person. Although it is fast food, there is a lot of work that goes into working here. Pay could be more.
Advice to Management: Encourage your workers to feel like they can achieve more

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: My favorite thing working here is the crew. Everyone is great and it makes it exciting everyday to work with intelligent and kind hearted people. And our loyal customers who always come in and make our day.
Cons: Some challenges would be the stress. But that is nil compared to the satisfaction that you gain.
Advice to Management: Communication is key.

Title: "Not a healthy work environment"
Pros: Free lunch as a benefit, opportunities to advance
Cons: Not a healthy dynamic among employees and supervisors
Advice to Management: Don't be so quick to jump to conclusions- allow employees room for personal life

Title: ""Challenging, rewarding, values culture.""
Pros: 1 free meal a day! Promoting from within! Amazing food. Very high standards. If you are a hard worker that appreciates quality then this is a great environment.
Cons: Underpays. Under staffs. Have had multiple managers and supervisors unable to complete the tasks that they expect to be done in an impossible timeframe.
Advice to Management: Realize your service managers are getting paid 50% of what you are making for essentially DOING YOUR JOB.

Title: "Make sure you take care of yourself"
Pros: The chance to move up is great. You can really move up fast.
Cons: Will be forced to work off the clock in order to move up. Make sure you documented if you are forced to. You can easily get burnt out.
Advice to Management: Make sure you listen to the crew. Because somtimes the General Managers know upper level managment is coming in and they try to make it seem like everythings ok when there here, but when they leave everything goes back to being hell.

Title: "Worst Experience I Ever Had In My Life"
Pros: Free Food That's About It.
Cons: Everything Else. They Work You Like A Slave. You Can't Even Call Out Sick

Title: "Chipotle is a great company to work for if you are a smart, enthusiastic person with high energy who wants opportunity."
Pros:
*The pay is great when you start getting promoted
*Challenging yet engaging, fast paced, fun experience
*Great opportunity with bonuses and benefits
*Great ideals, philosophy, and general positive vibe
Cons: *Work loads can be tough; however, with the help of the team, it is easy to get things under control
Advice to Management: Positivity is the only way to have success.

Title: "Yummy"
Pros: The food was amazing and the employees were great
Cons: Management needed to be better organized you get blamed for everything
Advice to Management: Do better

Title: "Hard work but easy to do."
Pros: Free food at each shift is a big plus. The community is often great, depending on the store and you can easily make friends that you will keep for a while.
Cons: Difficult at the beginning, definitely takes some getting used to. The scheduling is terrible, and you only find out your hours at the beginning of the week, making planning nearly impossible.

Title: "Fun environment to work"
Pros: Fun place to work, great manager/employee relationship
Cons: often serving difficult customers and expected to do so quickly. I believe certain things get complicated for no apparent reason.
Advice to Management: Become more social with employees

Title: "Learned a lot and would never go back."
Pros: There is opportunity for growth and experience is not required. Pays higher than minimum wage which benefits new employees. For crew, schedules are flexible and will work with school.
Cons: Lower management is not supported by upper management. For older employees pay is not high, this means newer employees are sometimes paid more than others and raises are as low as $.05 every six months making catching up hard. HR is not directly present or accessible making work conditions less than professional at times. Some employees will get many chances while others are let go without much corrective action giving making feedback and success inconsistent.
Advice to Management: Support your other managers and take respectful workplace seriously. Tell people they do a good job when they do instead of always finding the negative. Appreciate the employees who work hard and hold the same standard for every one. Chipotle does had great opportunity but is not every persons future so do not hold it against someone if moving up in the company is not their end goal.

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros:
- Meeting new people was great , being able to get to know every customer that came along, getting the habits on knowing their order was awesome.
- Teamwork was always number one
- Communicate was key
Cons:
- The leadership when it came to managing a store wasn;t always well.
- The manager didn't have faith on her own team.
Advice to Management: When it comes to management , teamwork is always number one, communicate is key.

Title: "Cool experience"
Pros: Learn a lot, Always something to do, good hours and better $$, Worked nights so I had time for school during the day
Cons: ALOT OF WORK, drama with manager, when things are out of control everyone gets frustrated. Lack of order
Advice to Management: Know how to manage people. Stop showing favoritism

Title: "Company is great, people/management is not"
Pros: Free food, chance at making friends, chance to move up positions for better pay but still a lot of work nonetheless
Cons: horrible hours and also gets randoms (on average I got 23 hours per week or $380 every 2 weeks. VERY HARD TO SURVIVE w/ living expenses. They NEVER like to give full time hours even if you request it) Very intense job for the pay, get used to the heat, bad management made my restaurant horrible, working with people of a high school/middle school mentality even though the majority of coworkers were in their mid-late 20's. Any ideas you have are shot down, priority on gossip than work, favoritism, managers yell at you to smile when they're the least likely to ever smile on the line
Advice to Management: act your age, judge people for their quality of work, SMILE even though you're a manager.

Title: "It's a lot of fun but a lot of work."
Pros:
if you give them a 2-week notice they will schedule around your needs, and even if you haven't given a notice, they will try to get you out as early as possible the day of. may sound a little bad but chipotle makes sure they are always one crew member extra so not much harm done.
you do everything so you don't get bored while working
grow into a family.
Cons:
too many hours, I am still a teen and I get scheduled 3- 12 hour shifts a week (11-11).. of course time goes by very quickly but you only get a 45 minute break and that's not enough.
if your schedule says 11am-4pm, don't expect to be out of there till 5 or 5:30
managers give you work to do and then they tell you to do something else right after and then say "vamos" 30 seconds later.
Advice to Management: you should think of the crew members also, because the managers can sit and talk while they shouldn't be and nothing happens to them even if the line is out the door but crew has to stay in line or they get yelled at. managers have more flexible break times. instead of asking us "what do you think the answer is", just tell us what the answer is and ask us to work on remembering it.

Title: "Demanding"
Pros: Free food every shift you work
Cons: demanding, stressful, unfair environment, management was terrible

Title: "Proud of what you do, yet hungry for more."
Pros:
- Fast-paced work environment
- Co-workers feel like family
- Exponential Self-growth and self-worth
- Flexible hours
- Easy to master
Cons:
- Potentially hard to learn (There's a lot to balance once you become serious about this job. It's easy to master once you've learned it, but many find it difficult to develop the drive to learn and assert their abilities within a store)
- Dependent on the team. You can't just come in and do a great job. If your team starts slacking, you start falling behind. It's just the way the system works, here.
Advice to Management:
If you really get into the Chipotle culture, you will find that stores are either run perfectly according to plan - inevitably phenomenal, best places to be - or someone's doing something wrong. Stores can be very prone to some people carrying others. Sometimes management may not schedule enough one-on-ones which, in Chipotle's environment, has terrible long-term consequences.

CONSIDER THIS: When you apply, your "expected pay" is taken seriously. If you shine in your interview, the hiring process will often involve a quick line of "You requested this amount of pay in your application, so we're going to pay you that." DO NOT request a low amount to look more appealing. I requested $2 pay above what I knew their standard to be and was hired within a half hour of my first interview.
Take this job seriously. It's very serious work that will train you well.

Title: "Amazing Culture"
Pros: Very positive upbeat company. Everybody is rooting for each other to succeed and grow.
Cons: Nothing. It is the usual cons for any other job that one has (not every job has perfect coworkers!).
Advice to Management: You're doing a great job. It's hard work, and you guys are doing a fabulous job growing the company.

Title: "Stressful, fun, exciting, sweaty, long, awesome, hard work, friendships."
Pros: Learning to manage a casual fast food restaurant by providing high standards with our foods and creating an awesome atmosphere for the crew.
Cons: some COSTUMERS are out of this world
Advice to Management: Visit stores in smaller cities and towns, we are ready for restaurateur!

Title: "Good company to work for with lots of opportunity for advancement."
Pros:
- Your hard work pays of in a few months time if you communicate that you want to advance
- Free food every day you work
- 50% meals once a day
- Feels good knowing you are serving fast food that is as healthy as it can get
Cons: - If you work at a busier store, they don't pay you enough to do what is required of you

Title: "You are just a piece of meat... like the under cooked chicken they serve"
Pros: A pay check. Nothing else really, they will chew you up and spit you out. Advancement is a myth unless you are "buddy buddy" with upper management. If you have any personal issues, keep them to yourself.
Cons: No work life balance. You are asked to do the work of 4 people on a minimum wage salary. It is a money hungry company with a false sense of family culture. Micro-managers in every aspect of the restaurant.

Title: "Great Place to work"
Pros: Fun, Great work environment, Meet awesome people, Opportunity to move up, challenging, Get to learn new skills, good pay, popular place.
Cons: You always get burnt. The customers get annoying sometimes. Very fast paced environment. Van't work more than 8 hours in a day.

Title: "customer service skills"
Pros: the food is so good n we are really busy
Cons: cant get everything done at once or on time .

Title: "It's not hard work, there's just lots to do."
Pros:
-The management are genuinely friendly and really want to train you/see you succeed.
-Chipotle tends to hire really upbeat people, so your coworkers tend to be pretty fun to be around.
-Free food, discounted bottled beverages and paid breaks.
Cons:
-The crew (your fellow entry level coworkers) are essentially your bosses. Ultimately, they do the hiring and firing. This leads to a culture of having to kiss everyone's bottom to succeed.
-Leaving on time (when you're scheduled to clock out) when they're busy is massively frowned upon.
-If you don't know Spanish, some of the crew will treat you badly just on those grounds.
-The high turn-over rate means constantly being understaffed and frustrated due to overwhelming tasks to do in compensation.
-The insurance they provide can't seem to make up it's mind on how much it wants to cover for meds and doctor visits. My costs have doubled for no explained reason, even though my needs and plan haven't changed.
-The management seem to never get the schedule right. Requesting days off or needing your hours changed because of school, even if done way in advance, is virtually pointless.
Advice to Management:
Please, stop taking your time on firing those who do efficient work but have horrible attitudes.
Remember that you're managing human beings with lives outside of Chipotle.
Do more sit-down one on one talks with your crew. The talks are essential and are hardly being done.

Title: "Employee values held up to standards"
Pros: Created a welcoming culture with a work hard play hard mentality
Cons: Hard to move around within corporate.Very structured with little room for creativity

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: Great experience overall. Its Fun ! You learn how to prepare and serve food. Your not just working in one position your doing many things.
Cons: If you cannot multitask. This is not the job for you.

Title: "I love them!"
Pros:
They are always happy
I stay busy
It is a great learning experience
Cons: Nothing is wrong with this company. I like to work there and I am excited to prolong my experience at Chipotle

Title: "Tiring job"
Pros:
Paid 12 bucks an hour which was higher than minimum wage in SF.
Free lunch
Cons: Very hard job working on the grill. The night shift griller had to cook all the meet and while waiting for the meat to cook had to be washing dishes or something of that caliber, The griller basically the cook had to make all the rice and clean the grill and the entire kitchen. The griller was a one man job which was really hard.
Advice to Management: Should make the griller a two man job because it is too much work for one person to do.

Title: ""The company of double-standards""
Pros:
-free food
-competitive salary
-great bonuses
-room for advancement
Cons:
-salary managers are expected to work 60+ hour weeks
-terrible work/life balance
-high turnover at every level
-double standards that change from day to day and restaurant to restaurant
Advice to Management: good luck

Title: "team crew member"
Pros: The benefits are good here. you have paid breaks so that is a plus as well.
Cons: Unrealistic expectation But then again that will help you in the future.

Title: "Cashier"
Pros: Great on paper! The values they stand for and respect to good food is great. Extremely easy work. Fast paced. Redundant routine work. Very simple uniform policy. Just a company shirt and whatever pants you want. Relaxed dress code; I have multiple face piercings and stretched ears, blue hair, etc. Time flies pretty fast. Free meal everyday. Lots of hours to offer.
Cons: Horrible management and Favoritism. Preach ideals and the idea that you can soar, but only if you're a certain person. Past work experience means nothing-pay rate is based on favoritism. Choose to promote under experienced workers over experience so they can "mold" you. You don't pick your work position when hired, rather told where you will be working. (Applied for Kitchen position with experience, interviewed for kitchen postion-got stuck as cashier.) The cashier IS the Janitor-store cleanliness is YOUR duty-no other position has to clean bathrooms, sweep, mop, ever. Young coworkers-lots of immaturity and call outs. Night shift is ignored completely. Everyone is supposed to have a weekly progress journal and one on one's with management (which is the way to be promoted upon completion) but only certain people do and the others will NEVER receive one. Forced to skimp portions and anger customers to save product costs.
Advice to Management: All the workers already know who's gonna be the next Kitchen Manager or Service Manager right out of the gate. Only certain people get One on One's with management-why is that? Night shift knows they are looked at as the lesser crew. The people with the most Kitchen/Quik Serv/Food experience were paid the least. Makes no sense...

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Lots of opportunity to grow. I enjoy coming into work every day and have a good time with my coworkers. It can be very stressful yet also rewarding.
Cons: Sometimes stressful, lots of multitasking
Advice to Management: Nothing, excellent staff

Title: "Horrible management and unrewarding, but you will learn good work ethic."
Pros: You will learn a lot, friendly coworkers, free meals, paid breaks. They are willing to work with school schedules. Potential to become manager in less than a year easily. You will always be working, there is no time spent sitting around being bored.
Cons: Pay is minimum. Night managers are not good and you will almost never get out on time. Managers regularly forget about breaks and you will end up taking 50 minutes of breaks in the last 2 hours of your shift - even if you remind them. Management also will not take responsibility for their actions, and instead blame problems on crew members. Crew members have been told they have to come in anyway when they call in sick or else risk being written up. They are horrible with time off requests and often they will tell you it's your problem and you need to find someone to cover for you even if you request a month in advance. Schedule changes at least once during the middle of the week and no one ever says anything about it, leading to angry phone calls from management when you don't show up for a day of work you were originally scheduled to have off.
Advice to Management: There is a reason the turnover is so high, and it's not the crew members' faults. The management is the worst I have ever had to deal with. Management needs to do their job properly without breaking labor laws! More people need to be hired, as we are regularly understaffed and it is impossible to get someone to cover work for a day simply because there are no people able to cover a shift. Training needs to be done more frequently, there needs to be less people who only know how to do one job, and more people who are able to do most things in the store - this opens up more people to be able to cover for breaks or to cover for shifts when people are sick or need a personal day.

Title: "WAS fun"
Pros: Great coworkers. We were a family. I loved the experience. It was hard work but with teamwork, we got stuff done. Free food and a paid 30 min break. Promoting from within.
Cons: The manager I had was NOT promoting anyone for a while and was paying the people that just got hired more than my older coworkers and I. The GM had a no gossiping rule when she was the one who gossiped the most. She fired her best people over little things because we did not kiss her butt anymore.
Advice to Management: Check your restaurants. The people I worked with were great people and would have become great managers and managing great stores. Not all of your managers are great and some are pretty terrible.

Title: "I really did enjoy work there and would work there again"
Pros:
Nice Coworkers
Nice customers
You'll never get sick of the food and 50% off
Can get days off
Didn't really have any coworkers that slacked off
Cons:
Lunch hour can be hell
Will occasionally get attitude
Advice to Management: Do not promote just anyone that has been working for the company for a long time.

Title: "KMIT"
Pros: The company has great values, real ingredients, real food prep
Cons: not enough training, too much responsibility not enough pay

Title: "It was a good experiance"
Pros: You get free food during your shifts and your breaks are paid. The people you work with are great.
Cons: Underpaid for the level of skill to work in the kitchen, extremely high paced environment, management can suck sometimes.
Advice to Management: Soend more time out your office.

Title: "Busy"
Pros:
Great Pay
Great Hours
Meet new people
Cons:
Long Closing Hours
Non stop movement
Get called in a lot on off days
Advice to Management: Listen to employees, try not to overwork them, don't pressure them to become managers if they don't want to be

Title: "Good Culture, but my location was a little unorganized"
Pros: Pretty good pay, relaxed, good opportunity to learn about franchising, good opportunity to try to move up in a management role because rotation is consistent to about two years.
Cons: no variety in work, management at my location was organized and in danger of getting replaced, inadequate training to start working the first week. I worked as the dishwasher/ dining room cleaner for five weeks straight.
Advice to Management: Make sure to actually instruct new hires what they need to do and the proper standard that Chipotle expects of its employees. It would be really helpful to show the new hires the training videos on the first few days before actually working, because they are indeed very helpful.

Title: "If it wasn't food, I would attempt to make it a career"
Pros: More than enough opportunity to advance in company, management works along side you at every moment.
Cons: Very fast paced, values can some times feel like they are in the way of productivity.

Title: "If you would like to advance and are willing to put in the effort this job is great."
Pros: The work environment here is so live. Everyone does their job but also has fun doing it. They do crew meeting and give chances for the crew to speak up about what's on their mind.
Cons: One big con to me is if you have to call in sick they ask you for a drs excuse on the first day.

Title: "Hard work, decent pay, great food and company"
Pros:
Free delicious meal every day you work
Paid break
Plenty of opportunities to work more
Encourage to move up from management
50% off meals when not working
Don't deal with many rude customers
High standards
Cons:
****Hard fast pace work****(this job is not laidback)
Work can get repetitive
Hours can be a little too rigid, make sure you are clear on when you want to work
Takes a while to get comfortable with the job responsibilities
High standards
Advice to Management: More proper training with new crew members

Title: "Great company and amazing food, but horrible local management."
Pros: It was great to be apart of a company with values that stretched beyond itself, food with integrity and the family farm initiatives. Not to mention the food is amazing!
Cons: Although the ideals of the company are great, there's no real follow through and accountability with the area managers. Being apart of a great company means nothing when you work for someone who does manage with those same ideals.
Advice to Management: Unfortunately as you grow your message will get diluted. I would follow Steve and Monty to the ends of the earth but not all of your TLs ATLs and Rs lead with the same results. Losing Chipotle was like losing a great friend, but I couldn't maintain the relationship any longer.

Title: "Good"
Pros: Co-Workers are very helping. The mangers there make everyone feel loved and welcomed.
Cons: It can be hard for a employee to give advice or suggestions to the managers about something from the customers.

Title: "Overall decent job"
Pros: Good morals and high standards
Cons: lots of labor, not enough pay.

Title: "Chipotle"
Pros:
If you like to be active in a job, you will always have something to do here.
It's not a boring routine, depending on your co-workers and ambition.
Cons:
Customers can get hectic. But that's expected.
Manager was extremely power seeking, had bad temper, took advantage of his postion.
Advice to Management: Cooperate should run a month to month secret camera test to really see how the managers are treating their employees.

Title: "Hit Or Miss"
Pros: The best part about working for Chipotle is that drinking the Kool Aid will open all the doors you can imagine and beyond. Chipotle pays better than a typical fast food place, the food is great and learning the job is fun if you're motivated to do well, have a brain, and like learning new things. It's usually pretty busy, which is a plus.
Cons: Some stores project an arrogant air of superiority. You can smell it in the interview, so go with your gut. If you don't gel with the managers (and possibly crew) you interview with, move on. It might be a bad store, it might just be that the store isn't right for you and the Chipotle down the road a bit might be a better fit if you give it a shot.
Advice to Management: Place more emphasis on management and leadership training beyond the crew level. The Chipotle vision and all that is great and should be engrained in the crew so that they carry it on through their steps in management, but the managers I've worked with seem like glorified crew who can't monitor the flow of business, identify and fix slow points, take care of food safety beyond the checklist, and might be more concerned with being everybody's best bud than making sure the restaurant is functional.

Title: "Working at chipotle is amazing"
Pros: You can make a lot of money and it has great opportunity that will change your life. I think chipotle is a great place to eat too
Cons: It is very fast pace job and you will have to try to keep up. It's not too hard but it is very steady
Advice to Management: Stay on top and Always believe in you and your team

Title: "Crew"
Pros: The food at Chipotle is always great so I did not mind being around it all the time. My coworkers were energetic and great to work with.
Cons: Chipotle will work you hard and sometimes it feels like we are being way underpaid for the stress we face during huge rush hours.

Title: "A great job for college students"
Pros: Flexible schedule. Easy hours. Good pay for students. Free meal every shift.
Cons: It is hard to move up.
Advice to Management: Focus more on developing your employees.

Title: "It's another fast food job"
Pros: Good food cool co workers easy
Cons: Annoying rude customers and very busy

Title: "A place you would want to start if you were working in the food management field"
Pros: Chipotle promotes from within! They have a great tools for developing people into management and the company takes really good care of their employees! We take pride in helping local farmers, having high standards and caring for our food..for the benefit of our future, the customers.
Cons: The only thing i could think of is that either, you could be under staffed or everyone may not pull their own weight..this could make your days over worked, stressful or just not a positive shift.

Title: "Don't bother..."
Pros: Employee meal, simple uniform.
Cons: training was awful, inexperienced managers, constantly picked favorites, they couldn't keep employees long enough, had to work off the clock, unreasonable expectations, terrible, inconsistent hours.
Advice to Management: Consider following the training plan. On my first day I was introduced to the menu in 5 minutes and showed how to do the tortilla station in 15 then I was by myself making the orders for the dinner rush with no time to ask questions just had to hope I was doing things right. I didn't get signed off on anything until they had their area managers come in and then the general manager finally showed me all the things I didn't know in 45 minutes after being their for 3 weeks. I constantly struggled to do my best but was over looked because people just looked after themselves instead of working as a team. Even the assistant managers were more concerned about their job instead of taking 5 minutes to show me what I was doing may be wrong or showing me the more efficient way of doing things. Finally once I did get trained on salsa my trainer could barely do the job themselves and the work load was unrealistic because with two people we still didn't finish so how was I supposed to do it myself. I was then quickly trained on register because they were low on people and I was trained their in 10 minutes and then thrown into the lunch rush. It was ridiculous. If you are okay with getting thrown into the lions den with no weapons in a meat suit then go for it other wise go to a job that respects their employees and works as a team. Not a place that is only concerned with money and their own growth not everyones.

Title: "Kitchen Manager in Training"
Pros: Great people, you learn A LOT about high standards in food handling and you build a lot of kitchen skill, fun.
Cons: Very low pay rate for the work you do. Especially working the Grill and Prep stations.
Advice to Management: Pay rate is too low.

Title: "It's been downhill since half a year ago"
Pros:
- free employee meals when working
- 50% off when you're not working
- paid breaks
- coworkers
- flexible scheduling
Cons:
- occasional favoritism when it comes to promoting
- high stress/overwhelming if your store gets high traffic
- lot of expectations
- pay not enough for what's expected of you imo
Advice to Management: - Please fight for the raises of your employees more and this is not to say that this applies to all managers because I've had managers in the past who cared a lot. Just doesn't seem too much lately with some of the managers that I have now.

Title: "Borderline sweatshop conditions, inadequate management, high turnover rate."
Pros: The only pro's are that you are making more money then when you did not have a job and when you have a spare minute you might be able to enjoy a meal that you made entirely yourself. Also you can become a manager in like three months because everyone quits and they need to keep moving people up to open another store.
Cons:
No one has respect for your off duty time, you will always get off much later then scheduled or called in on your day off.
All managers are catty and neglectful. They are not prepared or ready to managed anything much less a store. They will passive aggressively talk down to you, constantly watch over you (micromanaging is all you will find here) all while going and sitting in the office and complaining about how much more they have to do than you.
You will barely ever have a break and will always feel guilty about going and getting so much as a water because if you are not doing something LITERALLY every second they will either fire you or yell at you.
You can grow here but only if you give in to the bullyboy culture you are surrounded by. If you can manage to find yourself a clique or just a tight knit group of people who will literally just live at the store you will be very successful.
You will be promoted if you stay (because the smart ones get out while they still can) even for about 3 months, which leads to terrible managers. apprentices, general managers etc.
Borderline sweatshop conditions and borderline slave labor pay.
If you are going to be a part of a opening store you are going to hate every second from the day you open. The store will only consist of a few new managers who know nothing about how to actually MANAGE a store and a ton of people who have no idea how to be chipotle robots yet and manage the chaos. This in turn will lead to boatloads of people quitting because of the horrifying conditions you have to work under.
Working at Chipotle has been utterly terrible to say the least.

When I first applied I had no idea that this is what it was going to be like.
Advice to Management: Take a class or two about how to do your job properly. You are not just rolling burritos anymore. You have to worry about the organizational climate, schedules, deliveries, extremely long hours, math etc. and if you cannot do that, you should not have accepted the promotion. When employees are dropping like flies do not go to other team members and blame the employees who quit, stating they are why you have so much extra work to do every day but not getting paid more.

Title: "It was a decent job..."
Pros: Great pace for me, as it was much more hands on activity than any other previous jobs I had. At the location of my Chipotle, the people were very friendly towards me.
Cons: The pace could get quite difficult during lunch hours, as there is usually a lot of people that come in at this time. The pay could have been a little better, but not much complaints overall.

Title: "Very demanding job/"
Pros: They train you pretty well, but except a lot once you are trained. You do get a free work uniform (t-shirts & a hat), you also get free meals while at work, or before/after work. The top performer goal for everyone is a good one, but can seem impossible from time to time. If you like being busy the whole time while at work, then this is the place to be. Most of the people are fun to work with. The job definitely teaches you hard work and how to prepare high quality food.
Cons: They give you ridiculous expectations. These expectations on prepping food are basically how long it would take an expert to do the same, and not everyone starts out as an expert. The company literally expects you to come in as the best food prep person ever.
Advice to Management: Change the time expectations, hire more people. Up the pay, and maybe even charge more since this place is a lot of American's favorite place to work. I think the employees here are grossly underpaid for the amount of work they do, and I think people would still be willing to buy their Chipotle even if it increased a few dollar(s).

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Food, People, pay, experience , knowledge
Cons: Work, stressful , overworking, unfair pay, a lot to manage
Advice to Management: Learn stores vision : Empowerment , High Standards, Top performer with some type of example.

Title: "Great company to work for in general"
Pros: Pretty good pay if you actually work a lot
Cons: The management is absolutely horrible and unprofessional, service managers who got promoted don't do anything right and allow their employees to be treated disrespectfully by their own cousins! YES cousin! Not appropriate for manager to hire her own cousin(s), yup cousins, in the first place! Also, no conistenceny.. You can have 30 hours on week and go down to 19 the next week. If you're not appreciated by manager you will be working the weekends EVERY weekend. Not fair
Advice to Management: Stop promoting people who aren't manager material

Title: "The job is great place to work at the manager is very young and the atmosphere is pretty chill just do your job right."
Pros: Its great place to work because the managers make you feel good to come work with them they always positive no matter what happened bad or good the keep you motivated to go to work with a smile on your face.
Cons: Most days are full of chaos because it is fast food so we can have all kinds of crazies just got to act like they are right be kind and respectful the guest make you get headaches but at least the crew is full of cool people that make me laugh all day.

Title: "Horrible , Lies and B.S."
Pros: Food is fresh , sometimes. All the food isn't 100% organic like they say but they wont tell you that.
Cons: Where to begin? Leadership- Some of the worst people I have ever met. They lie right through there teeth. NO integrity, no follow through. They drink there own kool aid so much they think they are gods gift. They say its all about there people and team. That's not the case. They pick a thing to focus on and that's it, one month its labor one month its food cost. Not people. Why do you think they cant find people to be managers? Because they abuse them and use them until they quit because what Kitchen manager wants to make 11/hr and be expected to do the job of the gm? I was hired as a Area Manager with lots of restaurant experience. Chipotle by far is the worst operationally and has the worst leadership.
Advice to Management: Look at who you have in sr leadership roles. Very condescending and not honest.

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Great Career Advancement, great benefits
Cons: high-paced job requires a lot of effort

Title: "Chipotle is a fantastic employer"
Pros: Empowerment, loyalty, high performing employees, work-life balance, benefits
Cons: Sometimes still operates as a small company when more sophistication is required.
Advice to Management: Take care of non-restaurant employees, like you do restaurant employees.

Title: "Clones"
Pros: Great pay and benefits once you make management
Cons: Pick and chose what rules to follow
Advice to Management: Get better managers. Stop letting kids run the companies
