Pros: One of the biggest pros of this place is that the people working with you are really great. They remember each other's birthdays, surprise each other with birthday cakes. One time after we closed the shop, we played soccer outside in the parking lot for an hour.
Cons: They make you work a lot for the money that they pay you. There's never a dull moment, it's really fast-paced.
Advice to Management: Keep doing whatever that you are doing.

Title: "Awesome"
Pros: The food, people, you move up quickly in the company, and its easy.
Cons: If you arent working up to par, you will be fired quickly.

Title: "Stressful, unfair, overworked and"
Pros: Coworkers are fun to work with and you get plenty of hours, never bored.
Cons: Not paid enough for the amount of work expected to be done. High standards are too strict. Unfair favorites. so called "promotions" don't happen.
Advice to Management: Appreciate your crew members hard work. Don't tell them they are replaceable if they don't achieve your unrealistic high standards.

Title: "firing wrongly"
Pros:
good pay
good food
fast paced
Great pay
Cons: rude managers who have favoritism
Advice to Management: treat each employee the same and dont fire people because of medical reasons although they call in.

Title: "Chipotle is a well thought-out company that allows employees to move up quickly given the right management."
Pros:
Easy to move up if you are willing to put in the work.
After working for a year, the benefits are nice.
The food is tasty and free when you work.
Great culture and principles to understand.
Cons:
No work/life balance.
If you are looking to move up, do not expect much free time at all.
Advice to Management: Talk more about becoming Restauranteur with your employees. Also, talk more about the perks and how everything works when moving up more and more.

Title: "Chipotle is overall a rewarding experience"
Pros: Growth opportunities are amazing. You tend to have while you work. Time files during your busiest time. Health benefits are great for Salary Managers
Cons: Low pay for Entry level crew members. Always on call. Dealing with Children who are in management position. The Lack of drug test bring in more problems then they solve.
Advice to Management: Drug Test the crew.

Title: "It's Just a Job"
Pros: Free meal with every shift, half off any meal any day, bottled beverages half off all the time, plenty of chances to move up if you really want to
Cons: They don't listen to their employees very well, management is all related practically, the pay is fine for that type of job but the raises are laughable, certain people are listened to over others
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees because to them every concern is a valid concern and if you just ignore them, that brings down morale and self-confidence. Don't hire or promote someone just because their relative says they're a good worker and gives pointers on what to say to you to impress you. Just wanting a job, raise, or promotion isn't good enough. Also, once considered for promotion don't sit there and hold their hand until they pass the test for the promotion. Instead, actually train them until you can confidentially say that they've learned it, then have them take the test.

Title: "Big-Minded CEO, Small Minds Elsewhere"
Pros:
The CEO - Steve Ellis seems like a genuine guy with a great mind and heart. I was proud to work for him.
The Restaurants - Nicely designed, cool industrial theme, and hip music.
The Menu - Focused, fresh, simple, and tasty. This helps keep inventory costs down and the food fresh.
The Ethics - Chipotle supports a food system that eliminates or reduces the harms it causes.
Growth - Its a growing company with opportunities to move up from the bottom.
Cons:
My Immediate Boss - He was a minimal worker who belittled his employees and played small-minded games pitting people against each other. He was good a playing power politics, so he kept his job despite these pitfalls. The fact that he was also a serial wife-cheater gives him zero extra credit.
The Judge Judy Co-Workers - I'm a friendly, genuine guy who was thrown into a pack of wolves. In my restaurant, I was working with a lot of hurt people who spent their energies hurting others, like the people on many daytime TV programs.
The Expectations - The company expected people to move faster than human beings normally move, and this caused stress in the restaurant and harmed the customer experience. I don't like sweaty, obviously hurried people cooking and making my food, and that was the unfortunate reality at the restaurant I worked at far too often.
The Rio Grande Gap - The English-speaking managers talked badly about the Spanish-speaking workers; and the reverse was true. This reality created yet more petty dysfunction that took focus away from positive goals.
Advice to Management:
Be an industry leader by implementing a strong anti-bullying in the workplace program to make Chipotle a more attractive place to work for talented people, including the sensitive. Respecting and honoring everyone - your boss, the people you boss, your customers, and the people you see on the street- is always a sensible business idea.

Have employees engage in a steady study of what it means to be ethical. The values of the CEO were MIA at the Chipotle I worked at. My boss couldn't care less about ethics, and this fact harmed the integrity of the company and a big reason why I left. Being a boss means being a leader; and all true leaders inspire by example, by walking their talk.

Remember that you're managing/teaching human beings, not robots designed to be productive workers. But this advice goes to many companies, not just Chipotle. The future belongs to the companies that make their robots more like people, not the other way around.

Put less salt in your food - a Chipotle burrito has over 2,000mg of salt, and many health experts say that keeping the salt under 2,000mg/day is a sound notion.

By the way, I take responsibility and apologize for any harms I created and/or added to while I was employed there. I'm responsible for my choices, no matter what other people are doing.

Title: "Long demanding shifts, constantly moving and always something needing to be done."
Pros: Long hours, great healthy food, free meals/clothes great people culture that works very well if being used correctly.
Cons: No recognition, management doesn't communicate, stressful tense environment. Becomes very draining if everyone is not on the same page
Advice to Management: Communicate more with crew members. They do the blunt of the everyday duties, they need to feel like what they are doing is important and is making a difference.

Title: "Loving life at Chipotle!"
Pros: The people are very friendly, everyone is interested in helping you thrive and they are flexible about requesting off work
Cons: Everyone has an opinion on how you should be doing things and some even contradict each other. Portion sizes are strict and you can end up getting repremanded even though the customer asked for extra. The training program is not sufficient
Advice to Management: I know the training book is new, but its horribly organized! It should be organized by shift: Opening, mid-day, and closing. I still don't have a lot of knowledge in the book purely because I have not been scheduled to open. Also, our pay is a bit low for the amount of revenue my store does. My boss brags about our average daily revenue being 11,000 or more. Why is it that we make $8.75? Thank you!

Title: "chipotle"
Pros: time goes by fast when busy
Cons: not enough hours given to employees.
Advice to Management: be clearer in direction

Title: "horribleeeee"
Pros: free food, free drinks, not much more
Cons: no work like balance, barely any breaks usually cut short, "policy" changes every 5 seconds so you cannot keep up. Every manager wants something different from you every shift. It takes up to 2 hours to close. Major favoritism. constant schedule change and denial of days off, even if planned for months

Title: "An OK part-time job"
Pros: Co-workers, managers, company values, teamwork based
Cons: Difficult to move up, Stressful, very demanding job for almost min wage

Title: "its an OK restaurant."
Pros: i like the experience i build their as an employee as a first job.
Cons: they way the manager reacted through every thing was poorly and she should have handle things a little more differently and respectful, and i feel the employees should love their jobs and would want to wake up every morning wanting to go positive to work not the manager putting their employees down.
Advice to Management: i feel you manager should treat their employees fairly and equally.

Title: "Decent Place To Work At"
Pros: Coworkers were really nice, atmosphere and the food, pay was decent, organic and hormone free food, my restaurant was very convenient in location. You get free lunch when you're working and half off when you're not, you are recognized when we perform your job well.
Cons: Doesn't give you 40 hours a week, upper management can be a pain sometimes and the work can be hard. You're expected to know everything right off the bat, took me some time to get used to all the stress. Manager would yell at us if things weren't done perfectly, felt like I was being rushed.
Advice to Management: Managers need to be better trained,

Title: "Crew member"
Pros:
Good salary for fast food
Flexible hours
Free and discounted food
Friendly environment
Cons:
Heavy lifting
Smell of food (on body and clothes)
Poor development of crew members
Some managers are lazy and lack the ability to train property
Advice to Management: Train better managers

Title: "Ridiculous"
Pros: They are really good at convincing you it is a good job in interviews and during your orientation
Cons: It's not. It's pretty much the worst job I've ever had.
Advice to Management:
So, some advice for upper management. Let me, first, guide you through a story about how your general managers behave within your company.
My hiring manager was very nice, as well as professional. I got the job after two interviews, my first with two lower-level managers, and my second with one of your kitchen managers. My first question when I interviewed at Chipotle was: wait... how many managers does this place even have? Why does it take so many managers to run this store when there are only about twenty employees?
The answer, my friends, is because they are all completely immature, rude, and selfish.
It took Chipotle four weeks to put me on the schedule once they told me I got the job. I had to call in every week to see if I was written in yet, only to be told to call back the next week. Four times.
Once I got to my orientation, it wasn't bad at all. I went through about an hour of one-on-one with my hiring manager reading through the employee hiring handbook, talking an awful lot about hard work, how different they were as a restaurant, the restaurant's goals of becoming restauranteur (an okay idea, at best), and empowerment. They were BIG on empowerment. I think I heard that word more in four hours of orientation than I did in my entire life beforehand. They insisted the company empowers people, and that you will love your work, and the people you work with.
You won't.
Halfway through my orientation, I noticed a lot of people were whispering around, even coming into the clearly occupied office where I was watching my videos to gossip, only to turned around once they realized I was in the room. It was strange, to say in the least, but I figured it wasn't my business, whatever it was, and continued watching my orientation videos.
About an hour later, my hiring manager comes in to tell me exactly what is going on. Allegedly, my general manager (who I hadn't even met yet) slept with a crew member of another Chipotle during a party (apparently Chipotle stores get together and having raging, drug and alcohol fueled parties...). My general manager's boyfriend is a manager of another nearby Chipotle. Supposedly, they broke up because THEIR MUTUAL BOSS told her boyfriend about her activities during the party. My hiring manager confided in me and I told her I wouldn't tell anyone. This kind of high school drama didn't even wait for my first day. This happened within four hours of my orientation. When I was finished with my videos and ready to leave, I couldn't, because my hiring and general managers were out back smoking and talking on phones and crying and fussing up a complete storm. I had to wait an extra hour (getting paid to do nothing) just to leave my orientation. Easy free money, sure, but it didn't scream professionalism by any means.
As for my first and only week working for them, I was told I would be trained my first five days, and then I would be on my own, and should know everything. I was trained for one day by a very overly enthusiastic older woman. I was trained to make chips. I did that for the entire seven hours of my shift, with a small one to two hour window when I worked line and made food for our customers. My first day was tiring, but it wasn't awful.
However, as the week progressed, it got worse. I was not trained formally by anyone. ANYONE. Not a single person took time out of their day to help train me on things they didn't think I was up to standard on. I worked all morning shifts, getting to the store at eight AM. Between 8 in the morning and 11, there are three hours during which any single person at Chipotle could have trained me and still gotten their work done for lunch rush. No one did.
Anytime something was wrong, or if I wasn't doing something correctly, my coworkers felt the need to "empower" me (translated: yell at me) during the worst possible times, such as in the middle of lunch rush when I was trying to fill orders, or when I was trying to learn something on my own. Not a single manager trained me. Out of six. One cut the limes I needed for chips one day. That was one of the only nice gestures I experienced.
Anytime I responded to criticism in anyway, I was told to "not be so defensive". This included just saying, "ah, I know. Sorry about that, it was stupid of me," when I had realized my own mistake just seconds before someone else mentioned it.
The drama with my general manager continued during the entire week. I was approached often by coworkers, who told me to stop talking and work faster because I was trying to have light conversation and get to know the people I was working with. However, it was totally acceptable for my general manager, who gets salary by the way, to answer personal phone calls on the company phone and chain smoke in the back all day, as long as she pleased. It was also okay for her to talk and whine about her relationship to everyone and anyone that would listen in the kitchen prep area in the back of the restaurant. Everyone was free to take time to listen to her, but no one took three seconds out of their day to make me feel welcome except for two extremely sweet guys. Naturally, once those guys found out that I am currently engaged, they also stopped eating on break with me, as well as talking to me during shift at all. It was like working for a bunch of high schoolers. Not one single employee was capable and mature.
So, there you have it. The one week I worked at Chipotle. I wish it would have gone better. I did not anticipate it to be as bad as it was at all. I was genuinely shocked, and it was the first job I've ever had that I wanted to quit. I didn't even put in a two weeks. I can honestly say this place was the worst job I've ever had (and I've worked at Salvation Army!).

Title: "Miserable"
Pros: There is nothing good about wrkin at chipotle. Okay yea u get one employee free meal .... But it aint worth tht one free meal to work there nd get treated unfairly like. Slave !
Cons: The worst part about it is the management is HORRIBLE . There is definitely favoritism ! They give u such low hours nd want u to kill urself working . They expect u to move faster then normal nd do 3 things at one time . Never do the schedule right . We never have someone for dishes , dinning or linebacker for evening shift . So we're screwed when it gets busy in the evening ! Managers sit in the back all day doing nothing . They are racist nd discriminate against gays ! Its the worst place ive ever been . If u try to switch days or call out for one day even if u found ur replacement with no problem they still will purposely lower ur hours just for that ! They are unorganized and very unprofessional ! There is no leadership there ! Nd very disrespectful coworkers! Smh

Title: "Ok Job, I guess"
Pros:
Free food
50% off food at your home store
Can be fun
Cool co-workers
Decent pay
Helpful Restaurateur
Cons:
Being that I work at Chipotle on Lavista there are several things wrong.
-Management sucks
-Always working past scheduled hours
-Constantly rushed to keep line down
-Harrassed about doing something when there is no line
-Poor training
-Everyone is always mad when they actually have to work
Advice to Management: Help restaurateurs provide better training to managers and employees.

Title: "Learned/Worked A-LOT... Little pay"
Employee Title: Cashier and Crew Member Kitchen Manager
Pros:
There's no other place to learn about customer service better than Chipotle.
Company cares about you.
Free food.
Payed 30 mins. break.
Cons:
Co-workers ALWAYS complaining.
1 week off only per year, even though this is a fast food joint.
MOST IMPORTANTLY: you do SO much and get payed horribly.
They started to pay newer employees (teens) with no experience more than me (I've been there for more than a year).
It's literally all about the customers. We have to kiss their butts 24/7 and no matter how wrongly the customers treat us, we'd always be the bad guys and get written up for it.
They expect too much. You have to do 1-on-1's a lot and development journals. I had no time for that. I wanted to come in, work, leave. Simple as that.
Advice to Management: Treat the employees right. Increase pay much more for employees who've been with you guys for more than a year. Don't take the customer's side because negative web comments only gets those mean customer's exactly what they want. Don't expect too much from us.

Title: "Good place with the right management."
Pros: Fun environment, fast paced, easy work. Other than that, you have your regulars that you build relationships with. One free meal a day. and 50% off one item after your free meal. Opportunity for raise around every 6 months or so.
Cons: Some customers can be a handful, but you get that pretty much anywhere you work. With poor management, you won't be trained properly but you'll be badgered for it.
Advice to Management: Keep bad managers out. They bring down training, morale, everything about the experience.

Title: "HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE"
Pros: Free food, pretty good pay considering that it is a fast food place. It was pretty good until it started becoming stressful to a point where I was barely even allowed my five minute break unless I was working at least five hours.
Cons: Horrible hours, constantly moving fast behind a hot line, VERY rude customers.
Advice to Management: Give better hours!!!

Title: "Integrity, Teamwork, Empowerment"
Pros: clean facilities, upward mobility, flexible scheduling, pleasant atmosphere, great management.
Cons: communication problems, agency problems amongst management, upper-level management decisions which affect the workplace adversely

Title: "Somewhat enjoyable."
Pros:
-Extremely flexible with scheduling
-Slightly above minimum wage
Cons:
-Inconsistent management
-Duties not properly assigned

Title: "Don't do it!!!"
Pros: Free meals for the employees
Cons: Very unrealistic goals per shift, cliquish management, low wages, high stress
Advice to Management: Be more fair with promotions. Allow all crew members to reap rewards of Restaranteur designation

Title: "horrible"
Pros: Free Lunch breaks, good food, good people, integrity
Cons: hypocritical managers, no room for advancement, slave labor, very low pay for the type of work necessary, some customers are very rude,
Advice to Management: Hire better managers

Title: "UNPROFESSIONAL. The whole company is a bad joke, that only the managers can laugh at."
Pros: There is not one positive thing about this company
Cons:
Workers are rude, most tell you how to do things the wrong way.
Language barriers
Unrealistic expectations of new employees
Work load. Pretty much impossible to get done in their time frame
Rude, inconsiderate customers (people really have no class, they leave trash 1 foot away from the trashcan, even though they walk by it to leave)
Advice to Management: TRAIN new employees. They claim they dont have time but then complain about how the person does the job. You cannot expect someone to know how to do a job if they have never done it before.

Title: "Overly high expectations for an underpaid, overworked college student"
Pros: Co-workers became like family, great team environment. Job not monotonous, everyday brought something new and different. Challenging in a good way most of the time.
Cons: Job comes with the expectation that everyone wants to become management and eventually run their own store. The only way to keep the management happy is to constantly be pushing to move to the next level which of course requires serious time commitments outside working hours.
Advice to Management: A core of hard working crew employees that don't aspire to be management is not a bad thing

Title: "Chipotle's Work Environment is Horrible"
Pros: There are no pro's working at a company like this.
Cons: The Management is horrible and the workers are treated unfairly. There always yelling at you for the simplest things and lack the patience to teach you . You work late hours into the night which makes no sense because if the store closes at 9 pm there shouldn't be any reason to be getting out of there at 1 am in the morning. The Apprentices think they run the entire store and tell you to clock out and still work OFF THE CLOCK , which is VERY ILLEGAL . They also try to brain wash you into there way of thinking and try to make you live and breath Chipotle. The workers and team leaders are a bunch of losers who cant get jobs anywhere else because they have no skills and are all tattooed from head to toe !! That place sucks and I cannot believe they are still in business . Oh and being a restaurateur store is a joke !
Advice to Management: You need to have more training and have an open line with corporate to make this company work the way its supposed to.

Title: "where's the beef?"
Pros: Decent pay and schedule is flexible. Potential for advancement is substantial
Cons: Brutal shifts, extremely hard, fast-paced work
Advice to Management: Set an example by paying your workers like you pay your CEOs!

Title: "Fun place to work and lots of free food."
Pros: Good opportunities and fun work.
Cons: Hard work and trashy people to work with.

Title: "It was ok, manager was not understanding for full time students"
Pros: Great people to work with, good company with a lot of potential
Cons: Doesn't listen to requests for time off, keep scheduling crazy hours during finals
Advice to Management: Make sure the manager of the store is ready to be a leader.

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Working for Chipotle is as good as it gets for a part time job. Great salary, opportunities to grow, managment/leadership etc.
Cons: Sometimes the lines get really long and the pressure to speed up the processes increases but overall the pros outweigh the cons. Also it is very tough to move up the corporate latter.
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Hard work, they teach you alot, Easy to move up if you put in the work"
Pros: Great culture plus the company is growing so fast. Lots of room for advancement
Cons: Hours kind of suck. Tons of cleaning. Plus they get so busy it puts alot of stress on everyone working
Advice to Management: Be better leaders, they need to train managers on how to be a manager and not someone that just knows how to do the work

Title: "It was fast paced and fun. Got a free burrito."
Pros: Learned a lot about food and handling customer's concerns.
Cons: Really long lines during lunch time, we needed the crew to fold the burritos faster.
Advice to Management: I wish breaks were longer.

Title: "Seems like a great place to work from the outside"
Pros:
-Free employee meal while working, 50% off when not working
-Room for advancement
Cons:
-Unrealistic high standards
-During orientation they make themselves seem great with how they donate all leftover food, however that is false and we throw out pounds of food every night.
-Very long hours, if you are scheduled to one time, add two hours to that and that's when you'll get out
-A lot of workplace politics and drama....
-VERY high stress rate, job always on the line
Advice to Management: Care more about your workers and recognize their hard work... don't use us to get to the next level of your career.

Title: "An awesome place to work. Good people, good quality, and great healthy food."
Pros: The people are fun, active, and generally great workers. Pay was pretty good, especially to start out. The food quality is great, the company, managers, and crew care about doing a good job and everyone keeps it really enjoyable.
Cons: Can be a lot of work. They ask a lot from their employees.
Advice to Management: Get more input from the crew.

Title: "Bad really bad"
Pros: I don't really have a good experience with this crappy company
Cons: They want you to work like a slave. Don't have any type of respect for human
Advice to Management: Try to treat ur employees a little better

Title: "A great company that is all about making the employees happy."
Pros: Free employee meals every shift. Closing is the best (hint hint on the food).
Cons: As a cashier who works in the Lenox Square Mall in Atlanta, GA... the line NEVER stops for the entire shift..... Uuhh... Can I please sit down for a minute ?..... NO YOU (I) CANNOT! .... Why? ..... Because again.... the line NEVER STOPS.
Advice to Management: Try not try rush us so much to move the line....

Title: "Not worth the extra buck in food industry"
Pros:
- Starting at about 9 dollars an hour keeps you a buck above Taco Bell or other fast food.
- All the free food you want on your 15 minute break.
- Employee discount
Cons:
- Only Mexican management, completely racist towards white employees. Welcome to washing tables floors and windows your entire time.
- Cannot bring any food home from your break, you have 15 minutes to go to the bathroom, check your phone, stand in line to get your food and eat it. God help you if you're a smoker and need a cigarette.
- Schedule was NEVER up on time. Had to call in every Sunday night to find out if I was working on Monday. Good luck making any plans, ever.
- Inappropriateness and unprofessionalism due to poor management and HR policies.
Advice to Management: Stop being rude, stupid, and ridiculously unfair toward white hard working employees. You studied the book so you should know a white guy from NY made and owns the Chipotle franchise.

Title: "Great time"
Pros:
Company values their employees
free food every shift
job is relatively fun, they hire good people
Cons: Was often worked past scheduled hours

Title: "You'll never be fast enough."
Pros:
Free Chipotle on breaks (assuming you get to take a break)
50% off at home store only
Mostly nice co-workers
Paid breaks
Cons:
The speed required to work here is inhuman. It will never be fast enough.
They require certain cut sizes combined with super-human speed. Everyone runs around like chickens with their heads cut off. Always afraid of screaming managers.
They will throw away an entire hotel pans of product to prove a point if your sizes are not perfect.
They encourage people working off the clock. Service and Kitchen Managers are constantly coming in on their day off to work off the clock.
I was trained on knife safety after 3 days of working with a knife. With little to no direction prior.
You get a 30 minute break that you do not clock out for and most breaks lasted only between 15-20 mins with no proof of it happening so there was no way to challenge it.
Advice to Management: Stop asking people to work off the clock. The training videos are not being utilized as they should be, make sure everyone is on the same page with that. Hard work is not an issue, but the amount of things needed to be done in the time allowed is almost impossible. Realize that we are not work horses. Respect can go a long way.

Title: "Work hard, play hard"
Pros: Chipotle has a great mission. What they are doing with food with integrity is commendable. The atmosphere at corporate is cool. The company is exploding, so there is a lot of opportunity if you know how to make it available.
Cons: They will push you beyond your limits and ask for more, which can be good or bad. The culture is changing and it is becoming more corporate than it used to be. There are opportunities for advancement in the field, but at the corporate office, you have to make your own path as management rarely moves.
Advice to Management: If you're going to push hard, you need to reward those who are working so hard for you. Either work-life balance, pay, or promotions, the casual environment isn't enough to rest on anymore.

Title: "One of my favorite fast food jobs."
Pros: The manager acts like a leader among us, not a supervisor.
Cons: Takes a while to close.

Title: "I enjoy working for chipotle Mexican grill"
Pros: There are a lot of career opportunities at chipotle. One of chipotles policies is to care about their workers. They offer a lot of benefits, bonuses, raises, and other awesome things for their employees. It creates a comfortable and happy work environment.
Cons: It's always busy so it's constant work. It's better than having a boring job but from time to time the work load can get a bit stressful since customers are constantly lined up to the door throughout the entire day.
Advice to Management: Chipotles managers work for the crew. The crew does not work for the managers. That concept is supposed to make the work place a very positive and encouraging place.. This is very important so my advice to management is to always remember how chipotle managers are supposed to act in comparison to managers at other companies. If they fail to act that way it creates a very uncomfortable environment for us workers.

Title: "Amazing"
Pros:
Leadership skills
Quick movement up the company
Cons:
Hard work
Not much down time
Advice to Management: Sometimes people are promoted too quickly without proper training

Title: "Sucked"
Pros: None, they work you to the bone
Cons: Everything about Working for Chipotle sucks
Advice to Management: Shut down the company

Title: "Chipotle is NOT a great place to work"
Pros:
Free Meals when working.
50% off when you're not working
Some of the co-workers become friends
Cons:
young people running the company
too many little hierarchies within lower management
the friend's of the managers will get the promotions
sometimes when there is an open manager spot, the GM will pull from a different store instead of within
Advice to Management: Grow up and learn how to manage a store. A boss and a leader are two different things. Quit being so lazy and riding off the crew to do everything.

Title: "Better than Fast Food work. Still not what I enjoy."
Pros: Pays well considering it is a fast food place, easy to get time off and work around your schedule, offers insurance and 401k plan. Free meals when you work, so plenty of compensation. Learn a lot about organic farming and naturally raised animals.
Cons: Chipotle takes over your life, literally. If you choose to work full time, prepare to work double shifts with one day off a week. The paycheck is nice, but not worth spending all your time there. After a few months you will hate your job. Customers are jerks, your coworkers become rude, and management plays favorites. I definitely hate working in the food industry and this was probably the most tolerable jobs I had, but there are definitely some major flaws.
Advice to Management: Stop with the favoritism, train people before throwing them to the wolves, and fire people who deserve it.

Title: "Fast Paced. Fun Oriented. Hard Work. Horrible Scheduling."
Pros: Free Food!! You are encouraged to taste everything on that line and make sure that it is fit for the customer! Most managers are leaders among the group and that is always a plus. Almost every person you work with there is super nice and willing to help someone that is new or learning how to be the best at whatever job they are performing.
Cons: Some managers decide that since they run the show and make the rules, they are above you and while being "positive" and "motivating" they have a bad attitude due to the high stress of running a restaurant that is busy from open to close. It's truly a shame that such a nice company that promotes high morale can have people manage their stores that treat their crew members with disrespect. Low pay is another problem. The amount of work the crew does, especially openers and closers, isn't anywhere close to the pay you receive. I opened almost every shift I worked and I would do multiple cases of guac, which is extremely time consuming, and would get lectured that I need to move faster on opening prep and I was only making minimum wage. Scheduling is completely awful and that's really the only way to put it.
Advice to Management: Almost every manager who works at Chipotle has my respect because that job is obviously exhausting to do so kudos to you and keep up the hard work. To the managers who take their stress out on hard working crew members, learn to deal with it better or change your career field.

Title: "I grew up a lot here."
Pros: For me, the crew I worked with were practically my second family. We all stuck together to make each day the best possible, as well as blow steam.
Cons: It's pretty fast paced. You have to be prepared to do a lot of lifting and to know most of your recipes in the first 5 days of employment.

Title: "It's a hard job, but..."
Pros:
There's a lot of room to move up in the company, and most stores have a really great team.
The pay is really good compared to most other food service jobs I've had in the past, when I started out as a crew member, the pay was better than what shift leaders make at some fast food places.
Cons: The job can be hard, everything you do you're expected to do both well, and quickly. It can be very stressful at times.
Advice to Management: Managers aren't always ready for the promotions they are given, and at times an ineffectual manager can cause shifts that shouldn't be too bad to become more stressful than they should be. Overall though the management is great with just the occasional bad apple.

Title: "Great environment, horrible scheduling."
Pros: Good spirit! Always trying to motivate team, teach you early on, always on time with pay. Loved it when I worked, was like another family.
Cons: Horrible scheduling for part-timers. Random firing periods (almost no job security). Not very good mentoring for new employees.

Title: "Okayish"
Pros: Teamwork, busy, great food and co-workers are nice sometimes. It was a nice experience overall. almost all the customers were nice and regulars there so you felt like you got to know everyone. Food is good but you might get sick of it after a while. There's a lot to learn though so be ready.
Cons: underpaid for what you're doing, it was about a dollar under but it truly makes a difference. they would get your schedule mixed up so let them know a head of time. train recruits better, we are all human and make mistakes. Each manager teaches you different so when you do your job, they approach you saying it was wrong and you can't blame anyone but yourself.
Advice to Management: Communicate better and train recruits better.

Title: "Best job I have ever had"
Pros: The people you work with
Cons: The customers that come in
Advice to Management: Such a wonderful company to work for. The people I work with including the managers are some of the best co workers I have ever had. This crew is a very close knit group, I am excited to come to work and that is truly amazing.

Title: "Among the hardest of jobs I've worked, and the lowest of pay."
Pros:
Some locations good about promoting internally.
Many managers were quick to notice employees who stood out from the rest, both good and bad.
Free food and paid breaks.
Cons:
Often insane workload for the pay, and district managers who act on intimidation and negativity rather than positive reinforcement. I was told numerous time I was being trained for management, but those promises were never seen through.
I was often treated like a factory worker. And managers were quick to chew out anyone who they deemed a cog in the machine.
The restaurant is incredibly dirty, and while management says it was just our restaurant I heard similar complaints from other locations. We had at least a dozen mice, and on at least one occasion maggots in our drains. The dish area is often covered in rotting dishwater and used pans of raw meat. The floors leave my shoes smelling like death no matter how I wash them.
If the job paid more it would be tolerable, but it's a job that pays low enough to keep their employees fighting for hours. One of my least favorite jobs ever.
Advice to Management: Show respect to your employees. Stop preaching about your "culture" and "vision" and start giving your employees ample pay, hours, and respect. I would recommend a customer/employee boycott this location and search for a local option, rather than seek employment here.

Title: "Team member"
Pros: You are able to get Free employee meals... And can order whatever you want and how much you want for free
Cons:
1. You don't get any training from managers because they say they are too busy
2. They constantly talk in Spanish about you
3. You have learn fast and work fast if not you have a talk with the DJ (development Journal) it's not a good thing
4. They never have anything positive to say!
Ect. I can go on and on I HATE WORKING AT CHIPOTLE
Advice to Management: Train your employees more if you did that you will not have to keep hiring people because they quite or get fired.

Title: "Good Company doesn't pay much for the work"
Pros: You can really move up in the company if you put in the work. They provide a cool environment where everyone can be themselves.
Cons: Exhausting and a lot of pressure to perform. The pay is low for the work that you actually put in. Your put in a lot of pressure to save hours which means you end up working off the clock a lot of the time.
Advice to Management: Pay you managers more. They really work hard to make sure they bring business in. Don't throw your stores under the bus as well. We are just following your expectation.

Title: "Management is KEY"
Pros:
Fast Paced Environment
Great company structure
Food is honest and clean
Cons: Hard labor, not many people can be overworked for months at a time and handle it mentally. Unrealistic standards at times but all can be solved by more experienced and intelligent management.
Advice to Management: The restaurateurs really need to analize their management otherwise these fantastic stores become nothing but a glorified Salsaritas

Title: "Best job I've ever had"
Pros:
Flexible schedules
Plenty of hours available
Easy training
Friendly coworkers and managers
Great pay
Free food!
Cons:
Very busy during lunch
Sometimes customers could be difficult
Advice to Management: More all-around training

Title: "Overall a pretty good place to work."
Pros: The companies vision and what they are trying to do within the fast food market is amazing. Serving organic, healthy food in an easy, fast manner is changing what people think of fast food. They have a great training plan that helps you to feel confident in your position. They are rapidly growing so there is room for promotion in a short amount of time, so there is room for tremendous growth.
Cons: Because it is still a fast food restaurant, college students and people who are not highly motivated are attracted to Chipotle, so you still get those employees who don't really care all that much. There are some times where you feel as though your job and expectations don't meet your compensation. Once you move up into management and gain more responsibility the balance between work and life becomes scewed.

Title: "chipotle"
Pros: fast past and very out going people
Cons: more give aways and more friendly workers

Title: "I loved the food but got sick of having it every single day for lunch. The hours were very long"
Pros: My team was awesome, we worked well together and had some good laughs. Learning how to make thew food was awesome! It was quick and easy and it was great to see lines out the door.
Cons: Long long hours, management yelled in front of customers, not long enough breaks, grill duty is hard for one person and sometimes I got sick from the grill. The schedule wasnt very flexible, but if you can deal with that more power to ya
Advice to Management: Be a little more generous with portions, especially with returning customers.

Title: "Great place to work in another location..."
Pros: Great pay, fast paced environment, great opportunities to move up. Would definitely recommend over any other fast food restaurant. Can be a lot of fun.
Cons: busy busy busy all the time, dont always get a break. I wouldn't recommend it as a first time job just because you may not be used to the pace of business.

Title: "Not what I expected."
Pros: High food quality and cleaning standards. Meals are paid for while you are working.
Cons: The job is very routine. If you are okay with doing the same thing over and over again, it is not bad there really is no room for creativity. Also, unless you are handy with with a knife and do well in food production, you will find yourself at a disadvantage.
Advice to Management: A better focus on training would be my advise, especially for those who may not be so great in the fields of culinary expertise.

Title: "I truly enjoyed working for Chipotle."
Pros: Allows for promotions and movement into manager roles, fast paced environment, great food, great lunch
Cons: Rivalry among coworkers is inevitable. Although there are opportunities to move into management, there are often only a few open slots which leads to coworkers competing at high levels
Advice to Management: Ensure you are showing your crew members that you are a team player, work on the line with them. Also, customers like to see managers that make efforts to have face with the customer.

Title: "Fast-paced, but very well structured."
Pros: Mostly flexible hours, structured work environment, opportunities to be trained in multiple skill-sets, encourages team building, food is delicious
Cons: Very fast-paced, high employee turn-over rate

Title: "Good learning experience"
Pros: Wonderful people, very fast paced, great values
Cons: Very high turnover rate, lack of appreciation towards GM/ Apprentice from District management, impossible goals for bonuses.
Advice to Management: I watched three General managers get fired from my restaurant in a matter of a year in a half. I loved working for this company but more times than not I was acting as a General manager only after 2-3 months of being an apprentice. I honestly believe all of the turnover and negativity came from our DM. It was a great learning experience and it has taught me a lot. I keep in touch with my old crew and things spiraled out of control after I left for a different company. It's been eight months since I've been out of Chipotle and things are starting to look up for my restaurant. I'm still very passionate about my crew- Chipotle has this strange effect on people where no matter how much you despise it when things get rough you still can't help but care. Despite my experience this is a great company to work for. My advice to management is be a little bit more understanding and put yourself in a Gm's shoes. There are a million people who are passionate about this company who are willing to do whatever it takes to move up but please understand that life happens. We're humans too.

Title: "Management really involved and LOTS of opportunity to move up!"
Pros: I really like that they try to make the work experience enjoyable for their employees and actually care about your development and even what's going on in your life. Their goal when hiring you is to make you a manager. The training is clear and everyone is there if you have questions. (The pay isn't too shabby either)
Cons: The only cons would be that it can get a little stressful during peak hours and Chipotle adheres to high standards so if you're the kind of person who does the least...you won't succeed there but chances are they wouldn't hire you if that was the case.
Advice to Management: I think some managers could be a little better with motivation. Some of them end up pestering people instead of encouraging them.

Title: "Good for what it is"
Pros: Lots of free food, a good wage for fast food. The other employees were mostly young students, which made for a fun atmosphere. It's not too different from any other fast food job, but they do seem legitimately committed to their values. Plus, the food is delicious! Great if you need to feed yourself.
Cons: Long hours, exhausting, the customers can be brutal. I always got plenty of hours, but not everyone did. The work atmosphere varies a lot from location to location.
Advice to Management: Be more flexible about people calling in

Title: "Good experience"
Pros: 30 minute paid break, tips, great atmosphere
Cons: leadership, they make you take your break right away and you dont get another one, understaffing

Title: "It depends on the store"
Pros: Food is good. Steve Ellis was brilliant in his development of Chipotle. Everything works to minimize hard thinking.
Cons: The crew in my store tends to gang up on new employees, especially if they are not hispanic. My restaurateur/GM pretends she doesn't notice the things going on in her store because she doesn't want to change the way things are and if the atl knew of the sexual harassment, racism especially against those of African decent, and the short cuts she conveniently never noticed, it's all over. My GM lies every single time our atl visits and coaches the crew on what to say. They hire their friends and family like a mafia. Im a service manager and the pay seems good at 13 an hour but if u have bills or rent, that's just enough to roll out of bed and back to Chipotle.
Advice to Management: Look at how many restaurateurs and atls are of African decent. That should tell you something. I have a relationship with most Chipotle stores in my area (since we travel by bike, foot, bus, or train to get cases of food from other restaurants because the manager who is cousins with the GM who just got promoted, randomly placed a order for nothing but kids treys) and they feel like they work in a sweat shop but there's possibly hope for a 2 dollar raise to km or 15 cent raise if you "meet expectations"... Or your gorgeous.

Title: "New Hire @ Deer Park Chipotle"
Pros: Family Oriented Workplace. Staff is well knowledgeable as well. Free Lunch & Paid Breaks.
Cons: N/A!!!!!! :D So far this company is amazing!!

Title: "Difficult yet fun."
Pros: While almost always busy, very fun company to work for. Great opportunity to move up in the company quickly and to relocate to new areas.
Cons: Can be difficult to work with at times, especially upper-management. I've never worked somewhere that requires so much paper work just to run a quick service restaurant.
Advice to Management: Way to much emphasis on paperwork. Not every employee aspires to be a manager and to many upper managers, they have to place at Chipotle

Title: "Great place to work your way up."
Pros: Good amount of training and leadership shown. Get to strengthen skills dealing with working with others and handling customer service.
Cons: Might have trouble if you do not have experience working in a fast paced environment. It can tend to be really busy around peak lunch and dinner hours.

Title: "Always Busy, Usually Fun"
Pros: Free food every shift, flexible to work more hours/less hours
Cons: Have to work 7 hours at a time with no break on front line.
Advice to Management: My store has good management. One manager tends to slack of a lot but all the others are ideal models for me

Title: "A good job to help through school."
Pros: They work really well with hours.
Cons: There are times when the restaurant gets so noisy that the customers start to get annoyed and angry and then they take that out on you.

Title: "so-so"
Pros: Their products have integrity, so you can have some pride in it. Job roles were well defined. They do promote from within.
Cons: The management at my location didn't have their act together. The behavior of the management and employees who had been there longer didn't align with what was suggested by their training materials. People's personal beliefs were made a factor in employment. People were promoted from outside the area.

Title: "Alright"
Pros: The compensation was good, the
Cons: Working environment was poor! And always busy, if you perform less under pressure don't !

Title: "So much opportunity!"
Pros: You get 30 minute paid breaks, that you're allowed to leave the building during, for every 5 hours worked. Free meals when you work, and 50% off when you're off. Being able to set high standards and only tolerate a team that will meet them. An amazing business model. CULTURE, CULTURE, CULTURE!! That's the best part.
Cons: You MUST be prepared to work, and work hard. Lots of hours, which is kind of a pro as well. The high standards are unforgiving and must be upheld to achieve restaurateur.
Advice to Management: Upper management really knows what they're doing. Keep up the great work! :)

Title: "Good when you don't have any experience"
Pros: people you work with are nice and they help you, you get paid well enough, its pretty organized as well
Cons: doesn't help you grow, schedule is really wacky, its gets really crazy and you have to work really well under pressure.

Title: "Good company, needs improvement management wise"
Pros: Free meals when working and 50% when not working. Can move up quickly if your dedicated
Cons: poor management, always busy, night shift feels like it never ends.
Advice to Management: Look for people who actually want to work not just young people who want to stand there and get paid.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Free employee meals, very flexible schedule, great coworkers
Cons:
Entitled customers
Understaffed
Unpredictable hours
Inconsistent management

Title: "It was a learning and stretching experience."
Pros:
-Time passes quickly
-You work with people who have all had to start at the bottom of cashier
-Free food for breaks and 50% discount when you are off your shift
Cons:
-Not a great amount of training
-Draining
-Takes a special kind of person to work at Chipotle
-Constantly on-call
Advice to Management: Hire enough people so you don't have to call your employees on their days off.

Title: "Getting the job done and enjoying it."
Pros:
Free employee meal during shift
30 minute break
Great people to work with
Great customers to interact with
All employees love what they do.
Cons: Once on the schedule, it doesn't become very flexible. The schedule is set pretty much the same every week, so it's hard to pick up more hours.
Advice to Management: Maybe providing more opportunities to get higher up in management. Or allow employees to have a few more responsibilities.

Title: "Wonderful company brought down by human failings"
Pros:
First, the food - you can feel great about the product you're selling, you won't have to tell your friends horror stories about how everything's REALLY made, and you'll be eating more free burritos than you can handle. Chipotle's menu is 100% solid.

If you appreciate elegance and efficiency, you'll find something new to appreciate every day. Chipotle has considered every detail of their store to maximize efficiency and avoid wasted hours, and it's a pleasure to watch this finely-oiled machine work. Working in a well-designed, attractive store helps maintain a positive attitude on the job, as well.
Cons:
It all depends on your manager. There's many things I could mention, but the biggest issue, which ultimately drove me away from Chipotle forever, is the draining futility of trying to move up in your restaurant unless your managers want to help you. They will repeat the mantra that it's all up to you, that you alone choose your path, but that's simply false, and should be obviously false to anyone. That mantra is a way to dodge commitment to less-favored crew members and nothing more.

I switched restaurants about halfway through my 20 months with the company, and from then on I was stuck in limbo. My managers seemed content to trust my previously-learned skills absolutely when it would save them effort, but also seemed to lack faith in me when I talked to them about working towards promotion. I received little to no criticism on my work (in fact, only shallow praise) but apparently I still wasn't good enough. Nepotism can take hold very quickly in the high-stress environment of a restaurant, and unfortunately I have to conclude that's what happened to me. I saw less-qualified, less-committed crew members actively chosen (and "chosen" was a word my managers used, not me) for management development, even while I was brushed off with the patronizing idea that it was all up to me. In the end, I kept my mouth shut and just kept working for my $9/hr - an insulting wage for the hard work that crew members do.
Advice to Management:
In-store managers: Keep your promises. Communicate. If your crew wants to learn something new or try for a manager position, be frank with them about their prospects, and keep them updated. I would've been happier if my managers had simply told me I wasn't the right fit for their crew - but I assume they preferred to keep me around because I worked hard even when I was being exploited.

Corporate/high-level management: If you visit the same restaurant for multiple audits, and every single time the GM has failed to keep a promise to you, or failed to fix a known issue, you should realize that that's probably a sign of deeper dysfunction. If everybody is on their best behavior for you and you still see fundamental issues with the crew dynamic and their work ethic, realize that you're being lied to about the state of things. And, most importantly, listen to the crew. Talk to them alone, WITHOUT their managers present, and they might get the chance to tell you how they really feel. Don't be afraid of the idea that even GMs can fail - as I was told over and over, everyone is replaceable.

Title: "Honesty and hard work not enough"
Pros: They have a great concept. A great product and some great people. I loved my job.
Cons: They don't care enough about effort and desire or dedication to the company or the team. If you can't promote people in a timely manner your done. I'm not mad, I'm disappointed that I put so much time and personal energy into a company I worked hard for and believed in so strongly and was discarded so easily.
Advice to Management: When people bleed for you, give them more than a thanks your a great guy but go away. Live up to the "13" and treat the ones who have it better.

Title: "Fast- paced demanding job"
Pros: Great co-workers, free employee meal, and a flexible schedule. Management is always pushing you to become a more efficient worker.
Cons: Exhausting shifts! The lines are out of the doors the majority of the time, so you can expect to be constantly moving/ running around your entire shift without much of a break sometimes. Customers can also be very picky/ don't understand the menu, so you have to have a lot of patience to help them out. It is a lot of work for the hourly wage you receive.
Advice to Management: Make it easier for crew members to take off a day of work. There are usually not enough employees to have somebody cover your shift, since the restaurant is so busy.

Title: "Working at Chipotle is a breath of fresh air"
Pros: Upbeat, fast paced environment. Attention to detail in cooking and everyone helps each other.
Cons: I wash a lot of dishes. But this is to be expected, I am starting off as a prep/dishwasher.
Advice to Management: Keep actively discussing company growth and employee potential for development. It is encouraging to learn of the opportunities wit Chipotle, and it gives me incentive to work harder each shift.

Title: "Very pleasant and fun environment to work at, also can be very busy."
Pros: Co-workers are extremely friendly and welcoming to new hires. I personally am getting trained extremely well. Employees and manager are always very uplifting and cheerful, PLUS making people happy and smile brightens your day. Feeling proud about the food you are serving is a huge plus. Free lunch everyday and 50 % off if very nice to have .
Cons: it can get very busy and a little overwhelming but people will help you. Not enough hours and pay is not that great, but better than most fast food places.
Advice to Management: I know it gets really busy, but just take the time to get to talk and know new hires.

Title: "NO hours :/"
Pros: Great product, Free lunch, great co workers, great food thats about it!!!! pay is not good at all.
Cons: I was unlucky enough to land in the only Chipotle in the US that was constantly empty and had very little chance on getting hours.
Advice to Management: Management at chipotle are very kind nice people. They do lack real leadership skills though since most of them dont really have a college education.

Title: "It's been my college job for 3 years and it's pretty good company to work for."
Pros: Good for people with high energy, you can have a lot of fun if you are getting work done and every one is being a team player
Cons: It can be difficult when everyone isn't focused.
Advice to Management: Be even-headed and fair to employees and the party will rock.

Title: "Overwhelmed"
Pros: This company is very people oriented. If you want to advance quickly it can happen
Cons: This company promotes a very laid back atmosphere but doesn't take into account that when you promote young people to leaders you are not setting them up success when dealing with such a laid back young environment. Upper management doesn't understand how to not micro manage everything.
Advice to Management: Trust the people you put in certain positions. We are all adults, and if you don't trust us, then were not meant for that position. It cripples confidence and progression.

Title: "Hard Worker? Looking for Career Opportunities?"
Pros:
Free food when working, 50% off when not
Will be promoted if you have the work ethic and mentality to be the best
Cons:
can be a stressful environment at times
working off the clock multiple times a week

Title: "Decent pay for first job, expect to work, expect high expectations. overall, it's OK."
Pros:
Pays more than most fastfood jobs
free meal every shift
very possible to move up in company (very laid-out, bottom-up path)
huge learning experience
good company to have on your resume
high quality standards, they care about what they're serving
Cons:
you will work hard, from beginning to end of shits
very stressful during customer rushes
very high pressure from not only management to perform impossibly well
extremely corporate chain that drills their vision into your head, can be extremely annoying
they quiz you all the time on policies and store vision and other corporate crap (irritating)
Advice to Management: management is fine really, pressure from them comes from pressure from corporate. Corporate, chill out, chipotle customers care less than you think they do. in fact, some of the policies that are meant to add quality, customers complain they are wasteful and pointless. no big deal tough.

Title: "Great Product and Direction, Poor Leadership"
Pros:
Great food, free meal when working and 50% off when not.
Fast paced makes time go by quickly
Paid break
Great product
Cons: Work with a general manager and apprentice that spend 3/4s of their time in the office taking care of "paperwork" when other managers let you know there can't be possibly hours and hours of paperwork to do. Very hypocritical as they harp on you if you get on your phone or use the restroom for a minute if any customer is in line but will do the same.
Advice to Management: You should be the leaders, not the boss, big difference.

Title: "They underpay everybody (except the people in corporate)"
Pros: Free food with every shift, 50% off when not working or taking food to-go, nice managers, very structured work environment
Cons: They expect SO much of you and pay you less than even dairy queen pays their employees. Here in Texas they start you off at 8.50 hourly for crew and expect you to memorize a whole slew of things and work you to the bone in a hellishly hot and loud kitchen working with miserable and rude customers. Managers are grossly over worked and underpaid as well. Kitchen managers make 10.50/hr and service managers make 11.50/hour, and once again so much is expected of them and the job is absolutely exhausting. Once they snag you with a salary if you make it to apprentice GM or GM they make you work 50-60 hours and week and corporate is constantly up your ass about every single little thing. If paid hourly, salaried managers would make a couple dollars (if even that) over what hourly employees make. They keep people hanging on by teasing them with the idea of getting promoted to corporate. Their business model is a pyramid scheme.
Advice to Management: PAY YOUR EMPLOYEES WHAT THEY ARE WORTH. You lose SO many good people because you take them all for granted.

Title: "Fun coworkers but management only interested in moving up."
Pros:
Loved my coworkers, loved blasting music in the backroom. Pay was decent for basically no experience.
THE FOOD. Whatever you want during your shift and half off afterwards. The best.
Cons:
Management just wants to become restauranteurs.
Corporate watches you on the cameras and it's creepy.
My manager was not that understanding and gave us such awkward hours. 5:45-1030 pm shift...? and was such a slacker.... She gave all her jobs to others and did 'paperwork'. It's Chipotle... There is no paperwork.
Advice to Management: Stop advancing employees to management positions because they know nothing..... Super stressful to deal with managers that don't know what's happening.

Title: "FAST"
Pros: Free Food , Coworkers were great
Cons: Too Fast because of the quantity of customers
Advice to Management: Management was cool

Title: "Stressful and time consuming."
Pros: You have great co-workers whom you will bond with easily, great experience (rolling burritos, making "quesarittos", trying new things, learning how to work in a kitchen, the ability to have a say in who gets hired (democratic hiring/firing procedure), great benefits and chance to advance with the company.
Cons: Management. The kitchen managers were not very good at what they did (forgot to list items in the stock order such as utensils and napkins), a lot of hard work that is mostly busy work, working off the clock (unbelievable right?! we would get clocked out at 12:30 am and still would not be finished closing the store because of tedious tasks, very inflexible schedule), not having a service manager or GM. Our apprentice always told us that all crew members would be spoken to before a team member was fired so we could share our views on their work ethic to minimize individual revenge to get someone fired and so everyone could make a unanimous decision. Our apprentice would fire people and lie to the entire crew about having imaginary conversations with us about said person who was fired. Basically, he was firing people with invalid reasons and not asking the crew's opinion.
Advice to Management: The micromanagement could've been much better. The kitchen staff could have done better on restocking and keeping enough people on the line to efficiently move the line. We did not have a service manager or a general manager, only kitchen managers and an apprentice. Chipotle corporation should have every step of the management ladder filled in order to run a "restauranteur" worthy store. Always keep the store clean and dont stress employees out by making us stay to the point of free labor and having to do unnecessary deep cleaning to impress district managers.

Title: "Not a fun job"
Pros: Food is the best. General manger is kind and beautiful
Cons: Racists manager and co-workers. Unequal distribution of work.
Advice to Management: Train managers to be fair!

Title: "some of the best food out there."
Pros: great opportunities for growth, great work atmosphere, great food
Cons: it takes too long to move up past a restaurant manager position, and your career depends on how other people perform

Title: "ehhhh"
Pros: pay, and people, also the free employee meals that you get but thats about it for chipotle though.
Cons: hours, management, personal growth is based on who slaves themselves the best or who is willing to tend to every whim of management even when its unnecessary or uncalled for.
Advice to Management: at the chipotle in chantilly crossing please get a whole new managing staff

Title: "I didn't enjoy working at Chipotle at all..."
Pros: Free food and wages are pretty high for starter.
Cons: Super stressful, mean coworkers, very uptight management, and decreasing in work hours for no reason.
Advice to Management: I really enjoyed working at Chipotle for like about a week, despite having to face really mean coworkers who treated me like crap and always telling me to do this and that while they stand there and do nothing and they always leave you with the crappy job while they relax or do the interesting one, which is not fair. My coworkers didn't even help me when I needed help, therefore, the teamwork was definitely crappy. What's the point of being a team, if the coworkers won't even help you? I had an allergic reaction once and I couldn't breathe and no one cared; they told me to stop whining I'm not the only one who's allergic to things so get back to work.Then things started to go downhill after a week, they kept sending me home all the time and they never send anyone else. My hours and work days were decreasing like crazy to the point where I only work one day a week and for only 2 hours. I'm not even making enough money to pay for gas...and that's not all, even though I only get to work this much, sometimes they even call me not to come in...I don't want to jump to conclusion but my theory is that my coworkers were quite racist because I was the only asian there and they didn't treat newcomers badly, just only me. Overall, I really dislike working here, everything was unfair, and people treated me like crap...sad thing is, this was my first job too...and it's really stressful having people always yelling at you, telling you faster faster and do this or do that at the same time, I only have two hands, I can't do all of that. It's like they are trying to work me really hard on purpose...This job is definitely really stressful and with the bad treatment, it's not worth staying there, but don't take my opinion, where you work may be different. You might have people who treat you like a human being...But an advice, if you are looking for your first job, don't start off here, it's a load of stress to take on, mostly if you're a student.

Title: "Fun , fast paced environment"
Pros: fast paced, fun workplace, free food, gm meeting
Cons: rotating schedules, long hours, nights weekends
Advice to Management: care for your managers more

Title: "Calm"
Pros: Food was very nice to eat
Cons: The long hours and starting pay
Advice to Management: N.A

Title: "I love working here"
Pros:
You get a raise every 6 months and the starting pay is at $8.50
Good, Free chipotle ! yum
Cons: Have to work fast and efficient in order to move up

Title: "hard work, only good workers with a great attitude"
Pros: base pay, vacation, people culture, food with integrity (organic, naturally rasied)
Cons: ALWAYS busy, high demand, must have staff to run properly w/ low support to do so
Advice to Management: Have audits and corporate tools tailored to each individual unit to properly use labor and effectively give amazing customer service, while being able to have the highest standards in the industry.

Title: "Was a good experience"
Pros:
Fast paced
Energetic
Lots to do
Room for advancement
Cons:
Tiresome
Everything is time based
A lot of pressure to do everything exactly the way they want

Title: "Great.... At first!"
Pros:
Always hours available
Start off over minimum wage
One free meal per shift
Cons:
Managers are very pushy and sometimes plain rude
They over work and under pay anyone who is not a manager
Unprofessional work environment 9/10 times
Many times you are not allowed a break if it is busy(this happened even when I was 7-8 months pregnant! 8-10 hour shift with no food/break is unacceptable)
Reel you in with promises that turn out to be very untrue, which makes people quit(turnaround his horrible, after the 2 years I worked there I was 1 of 2 crew members that didn't quit in that time. All original staff I was hired with had quit, along with 6-7 more waves of crew that lasted a very short time. Speaks for itself about the work environment!)
Advice to Management: Pay more or keep a better handle on your management teams, any time a restaurateur came in for a visit we acted 100x better and professional than usual. Many procedures were only followed when we were being audited, total joke.

Title: "Fast Times In Chipotle High"
Pros: The crew was always the best part, they were the reason I went in everyday.
Cons: Heavy work loads, 70 hour weeks and only getting paid for 40 hrs

Title: "A waist of time."
Pros:
Free Employee Meal
4 hour shifts
Guacamole
Cons:
Under appreciated
Understaffed
Revolving door of employees
Empty promises

Title: "Unhappy place to work"
Pros: Clean, fast paced, cool coworkers
Cons: Harsh pressure on crew members to perform extremely well for very little pay
Advice to Management: Management seems unhappy and extremely stressed and passes that down to crew members.

Title: "Fantastic yet extremely busy"
Pros: Times goes by very quickly, friendly staff, great customers, extremely easy position
Cons: Not enough prep time, lack of understanding of upper staff, extreme tension among upper staff, short breaks, low tips
Advice to Management: Please listen to your staffs concerns a little more. Happy staff make for happy customers!

Title: "Your stability is determined by the department you're in"
Pros: Pretty good starting pay, great benefits, awesome corporate culture. The vast majority of people there are just awesome.
Cons:
VERY lean corporate environment. Depending on the department you're in, you will be told you do not need to work over 45 hours/week but you will if you want to compete with your peers who are working 60+. Favoritism is a factor depending on who you're working under. There was much to be desired in the area of communication.

My Exec. Director was fantastic but my immediate manager was not - this created major problems.
Advice to Management:
Be consistent: My Executive Director would praise me through the roof only to have my manager tell me the next day that my job was on the line - this happened several times throughout my employment. Ultimately I was let-go due to "inconsistent performance" which could also be said about the department in general; inconsistent hours, inconsistent expectations, inconsistent feedback, inconsistent staffing, inconsistent attendance of our immediate manager who was constantly out due to health concerns, etc. If you want your employees to be consistent, lead by example and be consistent as well.

Be empowering: My immediate manager was not empowering at all and would constantly micro-manage and spy on employees; to her, everyone (customers, coworkers, business partners, etc.) was guilty until proven innocent. She was very controlling and had a hard time trusting anyone with tasks whether it was us, our customers or our business partners. Ironically, when she was out for several weeks for health problems, the department managed itself just fine. Learn to let go and to trust the people around you.

Understand Work-Life Balance: Our department was worked so hard that word got to the CEO and he came down himself to individually interview everyone where he also determined that everyone was being worked far beyond what's necessary. My immediate manager works at least 65-70 hours/week and the stress is literally destroying her health. It was not uncommon to see her (or others) sending out emails at midnight on the weekend. Turnover in our department is quite high and good people have left due to (in their words) the favoritism, lack of communication, and dis-encouragement of work-life balance. Those who decided to come in at 7:00 am and work until 6:00 pm each day were not only rewarded, but held as a standard of work performance. Encourage your people to work only 8 hours/day and to go home afterward and you'll end up with employees who are more empowered and, ultimately, more efficient.

Have a clear-cut path for growth: In my department, there was no clear path to go up... at all. We were simply told, "Well, there might be a manager position sometime in the distant future." The more I contributed and developed, the more praise I would get from my Executive Director and the more my immediate manager would feel threatened and tell me to stop which is not only very, very confusing and stressful, but is also not empowering or a good example to set for growth. It is also highly inconsistent. I don't have much to say in the way of bonuses and raises since I was let-go just before my annual bonus was to be established and paid (a bit shady).

Title: "Promises that never saw fruition."
Pros: The food is really good, it's fun to learn to cook and learn their recipes, and there is a laid-back environment.
Cons:
The leadership at this location was flawed. I was originally told that I would be on a fast-track to management because of my advanced degree and experience in management. Three days into the job, there was a very noticeable drop in the training and attention they paid me. They didn't have a new hat for me, I had to wear some hand-me-down, and they only had a XXL shirt. I never got a proper fitting shirt, nor a new hat, nor the non-slip shoes they asked me to order.

Every shift I was relegated to washing dishes because nobody took the time to train me on anything else; yet frequently the assistant store manager and store manager would ask me pointed questions about my improvement and progress. Despite my previously mentioned education and experience (I have a masters degree in organizational psychology and I've been a supervisor at a fitness center), I was most often treated like I didn't know a thing, in fact, I was slow and behind in the progress they expected. Once, the restaurant manager lied about another crew member reporting that I had a bad attitude. I called him out about it and the subject was dropped.

To sum it up, they hired me, then forgot about me. Eventually, they blamed me for all of it when the restaurant manager brought me to his office to let me go. He took no responsibility for what happened (more like what neglected to occur) in my time there and said simply, that not everyone fits into the Chipotle culture.

I would never recommend anyone to work at that location unless they are fresh out of high school or have no other options, because that's all they hired over there. I believe I had a great amount of promise for management there and they let me go, meanwhile, they have customers complaining that employees are goofing off and shoving each other around the hot fryer.

Good luck trying to become a restaurateur!!
Advice to Management: Hire people who are a little more mature and people who don't divide into cliques. Also, that book for new hires' progression through training is a good idea, but be more dedicated to bringing out people's strong suits because that is the meaning behind human capital.

Title: "Chipotle is a place that gives you what you pay for: great organic, mostly-locally grown food, with high standards."
Pros:
No needed prior work experience, they look for 13 characteristics in a person to be a team member.
Quality food that is clean and served with integrity.
A great team environment.
Everyone has an opportunity to move up through the company if they are empowered.
Cons:
Lots of cleaning and contact with food making you coming home smelling of a concoction of who knows what.
Very mentally stressful.
Advice to Management: I believe that teamwork and communication skills should be advocated and implemented more in the environment in order to encourage crews to be teams and not just workers to elevate towards Restaurateur more effectively.

Title: "It was amazing!!"
Pros: they care very much about their employees. They always make sure to give them flexible hours and equal chances to everyone.
Cons: it takes a while to be able to move up the ladder. So if this is a long term job for you it will take a while before you can move up in position
Advice to Management: they should give more opportunities to move up easier. But at the same time they are doing very good

Title: "I love Chipotle's food, but never enjoyed the labor."
Pros: The perks of getting free food during your shift was amazing. This job is best suitable for a college student who does not want to cook, but loves Chipotle! I quit, but still eat there now and then.
Cons:
This can be a pro or a con but they promote workers to managers only within the company. I felt that some managers were not suitable for their position. Lucky to have a good GM, but everyone else, not so good. I'm a pretty athletic, focused individual, so they had me run the tortilla press. I made it pretty funny to force everyone else to basically go blazing fast, but I had to show who's boss lol!
In the end, everything is quite repetitive, but that's what you have to take in this fast and fresh food industry.
Advice to Management: I believe students like me could easily outdo the tasks required by the service GMs. If they hired service managers from a 4-year they would actually have decent management skills.

Title: "strong training program"
Pros: Great vision and ideas for training. Strong staff support for training with a good push for the vision of the company. The business process is smart and BO work is fool proof. The systems set in place do so much of the analyzation for you.
Cons: Compensation not in line with competitors. Do not expect to get paid as much as other companies and still will work a 50 hour week if salary. The promotion from within can be tricky if you do not fit the stereotype they are looking for. If you disagree with anything or challenge an idea then do not expect to get promoted.
Advice to Management: Advancement from within is great but not everyone is or wants to be management. Do not push advancement on someone because they fit the vision if they can not be a leader.

Title: "Truly a Great Company."
Pros:
