Pros: the only pros are the tips when you are a crew member
Cons: there is no proper training, you have to figure it out on your own, they will never tell you that you did a good job the only time that manager will talk to you is when you are doing something wrong and they just want to embarrass you in front of the other employees. To get the kitchen manager training you have to ask them a hundred time to train you and they will always say that they don't have the time to do it. After a year of waiting and waiting to train me they finally did and they told me that to become a kitchen manager I had to pass a test on a computer, that is was a new rule. And I passed this stupid test, they told me that if I would pass it I will become a kitchen manager but I didn't became a KM because they told me I wasn't ready yet. But they will promote other employees just because their preference or because they are friend and that's not fair. You definitely have to work to hard for what they pay you and for the 5-cents raise twice a year. It's really not worth it.

Title: "Fun but stressful"
Pros:
-good food
-fun upbeat environment
- great people
Cons: -lots of long grueling hours
Advice to Management: - promotions should be taken more seriously

Title: "Great Place"
Pros: Good yummy food and very health conscious. Good growing business with plenty of opportunities for folks that work there.
Cons: Get Fat while I work and not enough stock options.
Advice to Management: More food

Title: "Chipotle has great expectations, but recklessly fails to execute them."
Pros: Free meal during your shift. The quality and integrity of the fresh ingredients are probably the best in fast food. Hourly wage is a about a dollar higher than the industry average. If you can survive the dangers and politics of working for Chipotle, you have the opportunity to earn a position with great pay and benefits.
Cons:
I am young (20's) but this is still the most dangerous restaurant that has ever employed me.
-Horrible burns from needlessly dangerous cleaning procedures. I would clean a 385 degree tortilla press with just a plastic wool scrubber. It would melt and I would inhale the smoke, every night. One night I was burned on my arm so bad I was shaky and nauseous. When I showed my managers they laughed and told me, "Welcome to the club," and then they proceeded to show off their burns.
-You are expected to serve restaurant quality food with restaurant quality customer service without the tips. During spring break, aka 5 thousand dollar per day in sales, I would be lucky to make $5 in tips. Be prepared for people to leave all their trash on the tables without any kind of tip. Chipotle is high quality fast food, and the tips reflect that.
-Raw meat is being handled by people that are either uneducated or just plain lazy (this includes management), and when customers complain about it, management simply offers to replace their meal. Raw meat has dangerous implications and the current procedures at Chipotle fails to make safety a priority, for their customers and employees.
-During the training process, they push for employee accountability and loyalty, but in practice, the managers really just want you to shut up and do your job without questions. If you criticize procedure, then managers will label you as a complainer and make it their business to single you out for write-ups and fire you.
-Lastly, if you are starting out as a crew member, they will squeeze as much out of you as possible. At the beginning, they promise that working for Chipotle is different and better than other fast food companies. These promises are mostly hollow and Chipotle fails to inform applicants of the all too common dangers that are entailed when working for them.
Advice to Management: Improve safety of cleaning procedures, especially including the hot equipment. Separate equipment and surfaces that contact meat. Thorough education of how to safely handle and cook raw meat for all employees. Hiring procedure is sexist in the way that almost all women hired usually start on the line or register. This puts women at an disadvantage of progressing to Kitchen Manager because you must learn food preparation and grill procedures to be promoted, unlike cashier and salsa positions.

Title: "Hard work, low pay- not the worst"
Pros: Its an okay environment to work in. If you're a hard worker management will recognize that and show their appreciation by giving you the days you request off and will work with you to create a schedule that works for you. Raises every 6 months if you meet or exceed the standard.
Cons: Petty drama and bad hiring resulting in coworkers who don't work or follow standard procedures.

Title: "Great Part time job during summer"
Pros:
benefit
decent salary with great raises.
Cons: hours were sometime way to long.

Title: "Training? What Training?"
Pros:
1) The pay was good. It was $8.25 per hour which is 40 cents above minimum wage in my state.

2) I met a few decent people while there and gained my first paid work experience ever.

3) One free meal per day…that’s if you have time to take your break which is seldom. Half off a meal on the days you don’t work.
Cons:
1) There was no official training period. I came in my first day to watch maybe three or four short videos and by the next day I was working the line with the rest of my coworkers who had been there for a year already. Of course my coworkers had no time to explicitly explain the work they were doing so I just had to observe and pick it up as we went along. This resulted in a lot of contradictory information. This might have been somewhat tolerable if I didn’t receive a poor job review three weeks into my employment. My manager said I wasn’t progressing fast enough and I feel like my lack of training contributed to this greatly. How can I be expected to progress so quickly if I was never trained?

2) Lots of condescending attitudes. Managers, and certain coworkers, were in the habit of talking to you like you were 5 years old. Maybe that’s average in the work place but one kitchen manager was fired two weeks after I started for slapping a fellow coworker…that’s a little extreme. There just existed a general disrespect at this job and yet they wanted you to dedicate your life to this work.

3) Very many coworkers expressed to me that they had developed either Carpal tunnel syndrome or arthritis as a result of working there for too long. I too experience immense pain in my wrist after working there for a short time. It’s totally not worth risking your health in this way…

4) No one was on one accord. Like I said before there's so much contradictory information. So and so says do it this way and then the manager says do it that way. It’s crazy…you land in trouble virtually every day for doing your job the way you were taught by various misinformed individuals.
Advice to Management: Train your employees. There’s a reason why half the new hires have either quit or were fired in less than six months and it’s because they don’t know what they’re doing and yet somehow you want them doing it at incredible speeds. Also hold yourself to your employees standards: if you can take 5 million smoke breaks why can't I get my lunch break every now and then?

Title: "Loved it."
Pros: Very fast promotions. Lots of opportunity to grow.
Cons: Overall hard and tiring on your feet

Title: "It is a family you join, crew works together through tough busy days"
Pros:
Great Upward mobility
Flexible Schedules
Highest Standards
Benefits
Cons:
Very Busy
Sometimes massive workload
Common to get called in on days off
Customers are good people but theres always bad apples
Advice to Management: Try to see some conflicts within the crew more often and put a stop to them.

Title: "Friendly, fast-paced, and unstable work atmosphere."
Pros: People you work with are generally really nice. Work is constant and time goes by pretty face.
Cons: The store I work at is known to replace people often. You will have little one on one meetings and they will tell you same thing to pick up pace or to have more "character". Will ask you if you "really want to work there?" and to show them. Job does not feel secure even for people there over a year.
Advice to Management: I don't think the job is stressful for me. What is stressful is thinking you are always replaceable and worried a slip-up might mean being fired any moment.

Title: "Ok at first"
Pros: Free drinks free food and tips are good to have. The people are really friendly and energetic there are plenty of opportunities for improvement.
Cons: It's a lot of stress you constantly have to work at a super speed which can get really draining especially if you work another job and go to school. I started off at tortilla so I had to fry chips and taco shells which is super easy but it can really repetitive. After working there for two months I haven't learned how to work other positions. I explained to management I wanted to learn other positions but their only response was "but you make the best chips" they taught me how to make rice and pull beef and pork and still I'm stuck on tortilla I find myself resenting that job more and more and I'm still doin the same thing. Some days they ask me to work double shifts or stay long at least four times a week and I do it but if you're like two minutes late they blow it out of proportion. You do your work and work super hard but there is very little recognition for your hard work. If you like stress and mindless routines then this place is perfect for you. However night shift is a different ball game. You don't have to prep for food and even though the work load is lighter for night shift the tips are awesome. Which sucks for morning crew because we do MOST of the work.
Advice to Management: Recognize that your crew is capable of doing more than one thing. Change up the positions a bit more so that the job doesn't become boring. The management is so passionate about. Hippos but it's hard to get crew to feel the same way especially if they're stuck doin the same thing over and over

Title: "Great company, hard work!"
Pros: The food and the atmosphere is great. The standards for their food and their involvement in the community was awesome. The work atmosphere was good too.
Cons: It was a lot of hard work for not enough money. Every employee was expected to work as hard as possible within a very short amount of time. Frequently it felt like I was being asked to do things that would be impossible to complete in the amount of time given.
Advice to Management: I would recommend looking into how to expand crew numbers to assist in getting everything done in time.

Title: "Over worked"
Pros: Great food of course and fast promotions.
Cons: Promotions aren't worth it. Very hard work. Treated like a machine.
Advice to Management: Have more employees per shift. Listen to how employees feel they are treated. More secret shops. More help from ATL's

Title: "Not bad for food service"
Pros: Decent pay, good manager system...
Cons: It's a food service job, so it kind of sucks.

Title: "love working here."
Pros: Free meal when you work and 50% off a meal at your home store when you're off the clock. Very fast-paced which I like. Can be a very fun job.
Cons: you really have to work hard to secure you're position at the store. There is a lot of competition to move up in the company. Every time you move up, its just more work. You have to have a passion for Chipotle to work here and not loose your head!

Title: "a very intriuging job to say the least"
Pros: I really liked the Coworkers
Cons: Lack of leadership , hole in the chain of command
Advice to Management: Better background check

Title: "Love the company but its not for everyone."
Pros: Opportunities are great and benefits are unbeatable. Everyone is empowered to make their path and experiences in the company the way they want it to be as long as it is in line with their policies.
Cons: In the operations side, it is a lot of hard work for little money, from crew to management. But they've built such a unique culture in many stores that many people work hard for anyways because they care about the people around them. It is a team environment that works for each other. Changes are happening in the company to where they are shifting focus on "business culture" because of the company stock and because of rapid expansion in which is difficult to keep up with the need of managers for stores that will meet their continually evolving high standards. I love the Chipotle and everything they stand for and I believe the opportunities are worth work if your the right person who can achieve it. Its a big company and you can expect politics to play a huge role in upper management, politics is destroying the passion that this company is trying to inspire.
Advice to Management: There are many good people who want to be successful and are completely dedicated to the company. They believe in the company but don't feel that the company or upper management appreciates how hard they work. Eventually it leads to disillusionment and loss of motivation. At least believe in them too. Inspire them as you expect them to inspire future leaders of the company.

Title: "Middle Management and Top Management are corrupt"
Pros: Fun work environment, great team, high standards, fast paced.
Cons: If you are ok with working yourself to death, and never being appreciated for it then work here. This place is full of awesome people, but when performace reviews come around, everyone is average all of the sudden no matter how many goals you achieve or how hard you work. It is average to go up and beyond so good luck figuring out how to get a decent raise.
Advice to Management: Hold the same standard to your area management and team leaders that you do to your restaurateur teams. Don't be afraid to fire and let go of your low performers at the middle management level. Guess what, they may actually be the obsticle holding back their teams. I get that it may be hard to do that when they have dirt on their bosses. . .

Title: "Fresh Food, Toxic People"
Pros:
- Clean conscience, you're making beautiful food in obsessively fresh techniques

- Cheerful mentality, even if it's fake, it's nice to work at a place where people appear happy

- Some managers are truly motivated to make each store its own collaborative community
Cons:
- The promotion process is designed to filter out anyone who isn't insanely power-hungry.

- The corporate culture trickles down about as far as the area managers, who are supposedly one step removed from the CEO or whatever.

- The personal development journals are a cute analogue to corporate America, but are left empty until a higher-up comes to inspect the store.
Advice to Management: Work harder on filtering out the manipulative, two-faced management personalities before they make it to GM/Restaurateur.

Title: "stressful environment"
Pros: this job is fast paced so the time goes by fast. You get a steady paycheck.
Cons: bad mangement, stressful environment, to much work to put on one person. Some of the workers i worked with have to work really fast while others dont. Some managers don't care to help when its super busy. The managers are not trained in every area of the store so sometimes you will get that manager who will tell you to do something a certain way and you just have to listen because they dont like when you correct them, even if you explain your reasoning.
Advice to Management: train people correctly

Title: "It wasn't that bad."
Pros:
Good Pay.
Great co-workers.
Easy to move up in positions.
Good environment.
Cons: Customers can be a hassle

Title: "Fun Environment"
Pros: Some pros about working at Chipotle would have to be the benefits. I loved my coworkers! We all got along so well. The pay was okay, a bit above minimum wage. The atmosphere was so fast paced! Time went by quickly so that was good. The manager couldn't have been anymore nice!
Cons: Some cons would have to be dealing with some really rude customers!! People definitely don't play when it comes to food and they're starving! But I guess rude customers comes with any job. They were really picky about everything. You had to roll the burritos PERFECTLY! Cleaning when closing would be a hassle. They expected me to finish cleaning in an hour when I had to clean the lobby, bathrooms, patio, windows, and soda machine.

Title: "Overall OK place to work"
Pros:
Somewhat decent pay
Amazing crew members
Tips
Opportunity to advance
Cons:
Never get off when they say you will
My manager had a bad attitude to the crew and customers
Pay was not equal. Some people got paid DOLLARS more per hour than others who did the exact same job. It was based on favoritism.
You can't have a life at this place. The schedule is put up every Sunday. You can't plan to do something on the 26th because knowing Chipotle, the week of the 26th you'll be at work. Take off you say? Well, at Chipotle, you can take off two months in advance and you'll STILL be on the schedule.
Advice to Management: Have someone come sit in your stores and watch how the managers interact with the customers/crew. FIRE THEM when you see they treat everyone like 2 year olds.

Title: "Fun while it was worth it."
Pros: Free lunch, free drinks, tips, good hours.
Cons: Stressful, don't get paid a lot for all the hard work. Chipotle hires as fast as they fire. If you don't sell your soul to them, you won't get far.
Advice to Management: Instead of firing everyone on the spot because you fail to reach a goal under your management, instead give people a chance to help you more. No communication, stressful, horrible company to work for. Don't expect to be there too long unless you're one of the lucky ones to move on up.

Title: "General Manager"
Pros: Total Restaurant control, set own hours
Cons: Area manager would try to take all credit for employees good deeds and would try to trick employees to complete procedures incorrectly.
Advice to Management:
Watch your back and don't trust anyone, not even upper regional management.
Area management would continue to belittle and hold back the managers that excelled to move the preferred employees out front to be noticed, as to gain better numbers on monthly reports.

Title: "Hard Work, Low Pay"
Pros:
Lots of flexible hours
Good for a non-degree career, easy to move up
Cons: Managers are cut throat as they move up so it becomes hard to work sometimes, considering a lot of people never want to be manager.
Advice to Management: The only way to voice complaints is through management, there is no streamlined way to talk to corporate. A lot of time complaints are about management, there is a constant feeling of no security.

Title: "not an enjoyable job"
Pros: good quality food, use of organic or grass fed products was a plus.
Cons: most of the other employees spoke spanish. not an inclusive environment

Title: "GM Chipotle"
Pros: Excellent opportunities available at Chipotle
Cons: Work Life/Blanace is very difficult in my region.

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: The people and environment were good, easy to move up, free food while working, good location and easy to transfer between locations
Cons: The training was not very good because we were so busy, it is hard work, long hours always had to stay later than my shift.

Title: "Not Worth It"
Pros: free food (if you get a break during your shift), some people are cool.
Cons: no requesting days off, part time = 40 hours a week, no painted nails, have to be fast and always keep your work area spotless, long hours, do the same thing every day, get in trouble if your hair isn't put up right, managers don't work they sit in the office all day and expect crew to keep things going, takes forever to get a raise.
Advice to Management: let your employees request off and they'll be much happier - nobody is happy at my store because their lives have to be Chipotle.

Title: "Bad"
Pros:
1 Free meal everyday you work
2. 50 percent off on days off
3. Nice manager
4) Move up quickly if you're a very hard worker
Cons:
Very hard work, Not worth 8.50 (New york salary)
Rude coworkers
Very very long lines, Very hot
Advice to Management: PAY MORE !

Title: "Food Prep - If you need a job, it's for you. if you have any talents or skills, go somewhere else"
Pros: free food when clocked in and 50% off when clocked out. Few friendly crew members.
Cons:
Very laborious for the almost minimum wage. managers are underqualified and have poor communication and poor english. spoke spanish 90% of the time. i was the only asian and everyone else was of latin decent. i would never know if they talked about me. Very uncomfortable work enviroment. Line worker gets to be trained for kitchen manager and barely learned to slice bell peppers. no dish washer nor anyone assigned specifically for washing dishes makes closing the store ridiculous. if the schedule says your shift ends at 11:30pm, you're getting out at 12:30am. i was in the back washing dishes for 2-3 hours straight! Getting called in on my days off because of managements fault for lack of better scheduling is very inconvenient. The work required took quite a toll on me. luckily im very active and exercise everyday but this job makes it hard to do that. and on top of that, from cutting and washing dishes all day, my hands developed blisters and soreness. Goes away after a while, but comes right back when you work the next time.

Seems like anyone can be a manager, its just a matter of memorizing how everything works. But certain things are not taught to you or you are kept from doing a specific duty and you have to stay in that position. i have never worked the line in the front but i know 100% sure i can provide better customer service than the ones there. 80% of the time the managers are either in the office, or in the line, never doing any prep work. and if they are, its for a short period of time.

Also with 3 days of working i was never informed that i get tips from being a part of the crew. "If you don't ask about your tips, they take it", is what i was told. From a manager! seems like something a manager should regulate for fair treatment for all employees.
Advice to Management: There should be kitchen tools that would help efficiency like slicing and/or dicing vegetable. The time frames that they want things done are just unrealistic. No glove policy to wash dishes is stupid.

Title: "Alright job, overworked for PT"
Pros: free food, cool people, 50% off when not working
Cons: OVERWORKED!!!! (40+ hrs a week as a PT), dirty, smelly, never got out on time

Title: "Good"
Pros: good food, nice coworkers, attention to detail
Cons: tiring work in the kitchen leaves you feeling worn out after your shift

Title: "Empty promises."
Pros:
Free lunches
Employee discounts
Organic and natural foods
Flexible hours if needed
Cons:
Empty promises when it comes to "promoting" (they dont follow this very well)
Poor pay
Terrible raises
Poor benefits
Lack of breaks
Bad scheduling
Poor management
Favoritism
Poor training skills
Lack of teamwork and proper communication
Rushing customers out of the store
Obsession with becoming "restaraunteur" and obsession with the CEO
Giving certain people overtime and taking advantage of those people
Advice to Management: Hey management, look at the cons I listed. And pay attention to them. Maybe the company will improve if you DIDNT do these things >.<

Title: "Great college job!"
Pros:
Great people
Reasonable pay
Easy to work with managers
Cons:
Corporate rules
Different work schedule each week

Title: "Hard work but free food"
Pros:
Depending on location, culture is enjoyable.
Free dish with every shift!
Room for advancement.
Cons:
Late closing shifts.
Low entry wage.
Advice to Management:
Create more opportunities to get more free meals and pay increase.
Create incentives to work full time.
Create greater pay gap between associates and managers.

Title: "Work hard for not great pay."
Pros:
Initially getting hired at chipotle I made a dollar over minimum wage.
Free meal during your shift.
Easy to learn.
Allowed overtime
Good ethical food,
Cons:
Never received a raise after initial quarter.
Dealt with Racism constantly, customers are rude, non-english speaking employees assume other people can't hear/understand them.
GM was relocated and the SM did a poor job keeping things under control.
Stressful, when I was cashier I was told I should be able to move over 100 sales per hour. That's less than a minute with each person.
manager back up was always late when a customer was upset, then I was blamed for following the rules (eg. explaining to the customer meat costs extra).
Only received one shirt when hired.
Inflexible hours.
Managers took personal issues out on staff, favoritism, poor leadership, lack of communication, lack of management training.
Advice to Management: Better training for managers. They need to be leaders and good at communicating. Just because a person was previously a manager does not make them qualified. My stores had no inside hiring - they made us fill out leadership books but in the end did not encourage advancement of any of the employees.

Title: "Cult-Mentality"
Pros: Free food, friendly co-workers. That's about it.
Cons: Cult mentality, absolute waste of perfectly fine food, underpaid labor.
Advice to Management: When I was interviewed at Chipotle, I was asked if I was interested in managing my own restaurant someday. I'm a student; I have other ambitions than managing a Chipotle. A job that hires people "with no experience necessary" should not expect their employees to restauranteur their own Chipotle some day. Sometimes people just need a job. How difficult is that? I began to realize that this company hires people with the intention of them expanding the company, and ultimately making Chipotle more money in the future. I felt like their "ethics" were dismissed in the wake of this. How can I respect a company that prides themselves on the motto "food with integrity" when they throw away food when "it starts to look dry?" When you expose cooked meat to oxygen, it looks dry in like five minutes. That does not mean it's unfit to eat. This company needs of focus on what they stand for (ethics) instead of their capitalistic motivations.

Title: "molding great staff for other companies"
Pros:
food with integrity- amazing. setting new standards in the corporate restaurant world.
this company barely advertises, it doesnt have to. so in return staff is able to really take care of their customers. very easy going on comps, fundraisers, donations, promotional bogos etc
the food.
Cons:
they are expanding too rapidly
very low pay for work involved
restauranteur program is a joke. some restaurants have been granted restauranteur on opening day.
Corporate is getting VERY corporate.
the food with integrity is impressive, if only it was a full company with integrity.
Advice to Management: the stores are becoming more and more micro managed. have faith in your GM's and visit more often.

Title: "good"
Pros: food is good and the resturant is clean
Cons: No issues working at this place
Advice to Management: more workers

Title: "Former Crew Member"
Pros: Flexible scheduling, paid break, and free employee meal.
Cons: Trained a certain way by one manager and quickly found out it wasn't another's way of doing things which created a lot of confusion and apparently rendered me a "low performer" where I was verbally harassed and eventually in my opinion wrongfully terminated. It seemed as if there were more managers than employees, all of which were severally under qualified and on personal power trips. Employees including myself were regularly forced to work while sick/contagious even with the presence of a doctors note, which I thought was very unsanitary. The politics were terrible, and certain people generally got to fool around in the back while the person on the line was generally forced to do everything. I was regularly told to smile immediately after my job was threatened and was verbally harassed for being slow and confused from lack of formal training. This is Chipotles idea of helping their employees.
Advice to Management: Hopefully you're in it for the long run because you won't have a successful management career anywhere else.

Title: "great company"
Pros:
This company at least cares about the people they serve, the farmers they patronize and the environment. I have seen comments on here about the work being hard but ummm, it's FOOD SERVICE, it's gonna be hard!!!
At least they give u benefits and a chance to move up if u want it bad enough. The people u meet daily are another great incentive to work here.
Cons: Now it is a bit of a boys club. I can't say for sure but it seems like men move up the company way faster.
Advice to Management: Equal opportunity for women please

Title: "Good company, good values, good atmosphere, a little low on comp,"
Pros: Young, fun workforce, good benefits. Friendly. Good culture. Good product. good location. Food beneifts!
Cons: salary's are a little low, seems like not a ton of opportunity. same politics as any job.

Title: "pretty good-first time in a restaurant. they're very fair."
Pros: very friendly and understanding company, organic and hormone free food, very clean and safety conscious, only promotes from within, free lunch and paid breaks with half off 1 take home meal, says thank you and recognizes when you do anything, let's you leave if needed emotionally.
Cons: pays just a little over minimum wage, doesn't give you 40 hours a week even though stated did at interview, works you pretty hard-on your feet/pushed to be faster the entire shift.
Advice to Management: could be a little softer on staff and let them have a breather every once in awhile especially if break given 2 hours into a 7 hour shift, but overall very good company.

Title: "Fun and Energetic experience."
Pros: Free food, Not hard work, Free food, Stock options, room for growth.
Cons: Odd working hours, Some of the workers are unhappy with their lives.
Advice to Management: Hire people who will represent the company better.

Title: "weird, unbalanced, training not good enough,"
Pros: opportunity to advance, some friendly people.. managers are pretty cool most of the time.
Cons: everyone is a manager ... or atleast tries to be. its confusing atmosphere ... everyone is telling you different things
Advice to Management: not everyone needs to be a manager .. i understand 3 maybe ever 4 but when you have 10 managers and 12 employees things get complicated

Title: "Fast paced, fun, good people."
Pros: Flexible schedule, decent starting pay, easy advancement, good food.
Cons: Confusing management direction and training consistency.
Advice to Management: Study your teams and nurture those that have the drive to succeed.

Title: "I got to understand the business model, but realized quickly it would be a temporary fit."
Pros: free food, interesting coworkers, learning food prep techniques
Cons: work you harder than wage is worth, not considerate with hours

Title: "Not a reliable job to have. Horrible turnover rate."
Pros:
-- The atmosphere is pleasant to be in, it is not a typical fast food style establishment.

-- Every employee gets a Development Journal. Containing;
    - Checklist's for each stage of the employee's progression.
    - Weekly entry section to be filled out during 1 on 1 talks with their Manager.
    - Note's section for writing down technical instructions (computer tasks, inventory tips, ect.)

-- Paid breaks, every lunch break includes free meal.

-- Quick promotions*
Cons:
** Horrible turnover rate - 80%+ of employee's are employed less than 6 months. **

- Poor training. Assume that you will be training yourself on specific details.
- After first few weeks, expect inconsistant hours.
- Very positive interactions between new hires and managment for first week or so. It is just a front.
- Tolerates immaturity, gossip, and disparagement.
Advice to Management:
Recognize Top preformers and acknoledge them for their work.
Accept that low performers (no matter how "cool") need to be let go.
Enforce standards at all times, not just before inspections and corprate visits.

Title: "Poor Selection in Management, but great company to work for."
Pros: Free Food when working shifts
Cons:
Schedule and hours would vary unexpectedly week to week
Very repetitive environment
Advice to Management:
Empower employees
Engage with the crew members regularly instead of spending time watching the cameras and what crew members are not doing instead of being on the floor.

Title: "Everyone should have a job in the food industry at some point in their lives"
Pros: When I first started working there the management was great. They were really understanding about schedules, my coworkers were really friendly and helpful training, and everyone worked together really well.
Cons: After working for about 6 months, the management changed, some of the new hirees were not good workers and because of that, I was required to work more hours and have to do work that my coworkers weren't doing in addition to my own.

Title: "Tough job... You earn every cent you make."
Pros: 1 free employee meal per shift worked, 50% meals when not working, and paid 30 minute breaks for every shift worked. Compensation is decent. Delicious food.
Cons: Difficult to move up... Kitchen Manager is a challenging job. Not impossible to attain, but it takes a lot of training. This is not really a good first job, as it can be quite stressful at times.

Title: "Broken promises"
Pros: Free food, fair pay, ability to move up the corporate ladder
Cons: Physically demanding, always changing procedures, carpal tunnel syndrome, empty promises, no work life balance, you have to pretend you are super excited to be at work ALL THE TIME or you will be fired even if you are a great worker.
Advice to Management: Make sure managers are really ready before promoting them and don't make empty promises.

Title: "Very good for keeping someone busy all day"
Pros:
On your feet all day
Always something to do
good pay
good hours
Cons:
Chaotic
Managers do not always help out

Title: "Hard work that usually pays off."
Pros: This company actually believes in what it is trying to do. They hire people with great personalities and hard workers. Those who can not make it or do not pull their own weight are let go. The opportunities they boast about are real. Anyone who tries hard enough can and will become management.
Cons: The work is very physically taxing. Any disabilities will hold back the development of an employee quickly. This job is not made for everyone.

Title: "High standards"
Pros: It has a great business culture. Very clean, and nothing to hide. You get a free meal on days you work. If not, you get 50% off if you buy from that store.
Cons: None so far, other than the fact that we are short on employees. I understand that it's hard to hire in Malibu.

Title: "Food with Integrity/Not People with Ingrity"
Pros: Chipotle offers a great quality of life along with some great benefits not seen in the industry. The hours are easy for the industry.
Cons: Chipotle treats their employees with more respect then their managers. If you hire someone, they better be good enough to move up the chain or you get in trouble.
Advice to Management: If you really cared about how animals were treated then why would you kill them in the first place. Treat them right and then lead them to slaughter just like you did with all your older managers once you used them up. You advertise that 97% of your managers started out as crew. That is a hard one to swallow considering how big you are now. You must consider the service manager as crew to get that number. Before they went public we had the FOS plan. Friends of Steve were hired in and given great stock options. Must take care of your high school buddies even if they have no clue on running a restaurant.

Title: "Not as great as it looks..."
Pros: The people I've worked with, the pay was higher than my city's minimum wage.
Cons: Chipotle works their employees like a dog. They make sure they get every single penny you're working for out of you & you go home with nothing but sore muscles. I think the pay isn't worth what you have to do to work there. Which is why I found a better job that appreciated me and decided to pay me higher because I was a "great employee w/ plenty of experience"
Advice to Management: Stop promoting people that aren't ready. I felt like a lot of them would just give people the job because they wanted it, well it takes training for a longer period than just a couple weeks in another city. Another thing was that people at the Chipotle I worked at would get hired, hated it and then quit like 1-3 months after. I've never witnessed anyone that was hired stay for longer. The manager also hired way too many people a week that the hours got really short & people were working 6 hours a week which isn't fair at all. Overall, my manager was not good at what she did.

Title: "Good but stressfull"
Pros: Pros: family atmosphere but created by the leaders, good benefits
Cons: Cons: hard to seperate life/work. Double standards and favoritism
Advice to Management: Listen to your crew, on all levels of management. Respect and know your people and speak up for what is right.

Title: "Inconsistant with their views as a company"
Pros: I like the high standards we live and breathe by. The care we have for our customers is AWESOME. This would be a great "first job" or someone who is willing to give their soul to the company.
Cons: I wish Chipotle cared about our employees as much as the customers, especially wages since this is a restraunt and not fast food. In my state there are no break requirements, so about half of the time we do not get a break at our store, meaning no food in our stomachs for at least 7+ hours. From my personal experience, there is a lot of favoritism from management which makes other hard working employees frustrated.
Advice to Management: Wages should not be based on personal relationships between manager and crew.. It should be based on hard work and dedication.

Title: "Lots of Opportunity"
Pros: I really liked how Chipotle practiced what they preached with the company model of, "Food with Integrity." Chipotle aims to do everything in their business the right and ethical way when it comes to the food and treating their people. Fast paced working environment that makes work go by insanely fast. I remember working shifts that were 7 and a half hours long but they felt half the time once my shift was over. Work is an everyday challenge that constantly challenges you to better yourself.
Cons: Managers are promoted very quickly often with very little experience as to what their positions responsibilities are. Management also needs to stay true to what they promise their employees. I can remember countless times that my GM told me I was going to move up to be a KM and later be service manager. Almost a whole year later after being one of the highest top performers in my restaurant management still did not promote me to a KM. The highest position I got to was Fax Manager which was alot of work for very little pay. Work often overflowed into my personal time. I love Chipotle and everything they stand for but was very disappointed in the management.
Advice to Management: To reiterate what I said management needs to stay true to they promise. If you move higher up in management please understand your role and responsibilities. Ive had great talented managers and others that were horrible.

Title: "I learned much while working for Chipotle"
Pros: Free food and 50% when off the clock
Cons: Only employee discount at the Chipotle you work.

Title: "For what is was, great."
Pros: Free food, great people, good atmosphere.
Cons: Its fast food. It may be upscale fast food, but its still fast food and you will smell like tortilla chip fryer grease when you go home.

Title: "Crew Sucks, Food is good"
Pros: The food is good, you get a free meal after you work a shift
Cons: The perpetual rush-hour lines are stressful, people can be nasty

Title: "Over worked for little pay"
Pros: free food and 50% off( off shift) within the store which you are employed from
Cons: low pay and over worked

Title: "time consuming"
Pros: free uniforms paid breaks free food
Cons: Bosses make promises but take months to make it happen

Title: "Okay, But not for everyone"
Pros: Good food, Room for Advancement , Generally good people , it can be a good experience if the situation is right. , Decent pay
Cons: Crazy high standards , They expect everything to be done so quickly , which is fine , but the working conditions are inconsistent , its easy to find a flow with something then come in the next day, have to do it a completely different way and still be expected to get the same times you've been getting. They also DON'T hesitate to fire people. There is a VERY high turnover, At LEAST 1-2 people get fired each month, some for just being slower than other people. When people get fired the remaining crew is expected to pick up the slack meaning youll be working doubles , closing the store then opening the very next morning. IF your willing to make chipotle your life ,you'll be fine , anyone else STAY AWAY!!!
Advice to Management: Its Okay to have standards , but you need SOME flexibility within those standards , every day isn't the same

Title: "Horrible!"
Pros:
One free meal when you work and 50% off meals on your day off.
My manager was nice (kitchen managers and some other employees weren't so nice)
Cons: After reading a few reviews on glassdoor i noticed people complained alot about this job but i just figured maybe it wasn't true so i went ahead and applied and got the job. Im usually a hard worker but i quit after 4 days! All the work they make you do is definitely not worth 8.50 (new york pay) ! The lunch rush is the worst, im moving extremely fast and still get yelled at for not moving fast enough. (to the point that i almost cried) Not to mention everyday my fingers were burning because all the hot stuff (from frying the chips and making the taco shells having to touch it while its covered in very hot oil [you have to wear like 5 gloves] then when working the line you have to replace the food to make it fresh like every 5 minutes and its always burning hot cause the water underneath) and when you're not doing all that you have to make sure to sweep the floors and clean the counter every 10 minutes . and theres more that i will not go into detail about. NEVER AGAIN!
Advice to Management: if you're going to treat your employees like slaves at least pay them more!

Title: "Great Opportunity to Work Hard"
Pros:
Great Crew and Managers
Great opportunity to learn on the job
Skills will transfer well to similar jobs, giving me a leg up
Structured training system
Cons:
Strict hours
Schedules are not ready until the weekend before the schedule starts. (You don't know if you are working on Monday until Saturday or Sunday.)
The work is demanding and the same thing everyday. The only things that change are the quantities of prep and most of the customers are: rice without cilantro, chips in the bowl, cilantro on the side,...)

Title: "Prep, Grill, and Line Team Member"
Pros: The food is good and the quality ingredients are something a person can be proud of serving. The store I worked at had a very flexible schedule (I was a university student at the time). The other employees were generally very good, but some were not of the highest caliber. They comp lunch while working and 50% on days off. This plus the quality food made me eat there much more often.
Cons: The pay is low or at minimum wage, but set by the hiring manager so there may be some room for negotiation. This is still counter service so coworkers are sometimes not the best / brightest people to work with. However, that being said, most guests who come into Chipotle are happy to be there which makes for a more pleasant work atmosphere.
Advice to Management: The management is really good from what I have seen.

Title: "OCD about almost everything!"
Pros: The people you work with are great. You get payed lunch and a free meal. They train you to be a manager in as little as 3 months.
Cons: You have to memorize a lot of things in order to actually succed in the company. They are very strict about a lot of things. The managaer changes the schedule 2 - 3 times a week. they puch to be perfect. You can only get one thing for half the price when you are not working there. The raises suck.
Advice to Management: HIre less people and give them more hours.

Title: "Cashier"
Pros: You get plenty of hours
Cons:
-They don't pay you nearly enough for the amount of work you're required to do.
-They don't treat you with the respect to move forward in the company, they are worried to hire good workers due to the fact they don't want their jobs being taken.
-They will hire dirty people that don't have a great appearance to promote the company in a positive way.
Advice to Management: Give your "good" workers a chance and step up your game if you're worried about getting your job taken. Hire better workers, because this reflects your store which ultimately reflects YOU.

Title: "Stay Away From Chipotle"
Pros: The only pro is that you get free food during your breaks and discount on food on your days off.
Cons:
Management tends to be completely incompetent, scheduling was changed without proper notification, pay was minimal, time-management expectations were often unrealistic for back of the house staff.
Concerns of the staff went unheard nearly one hundred percent of the time.

There is very little in the way of career development and very few opportunities to actually move up the ladder with this company.
Advice to Management: Management needs to learn to listen to the employees concerns and perform the simple things such as making sure orders were done correctly, equipment is functional, and scheduling is done in a way which actually allows everything to get done correctly.

Title: "Prep Cook"
Pros: Fast paced work environment, good people to work with,
Cons: Expect far to much for what you get payed.

Title: "Too much stress."
Pros:
Paid Breaks
Free food while on the clock and 50% off while off the clock.
Cons:
Short staffed in most area stores
Overworked/doing two or three jobs in a shift
Focused too much on cleaning and "cut sizes" rather than customer service.
Not friendly towards high school and college schedules
Advice to Management:
When I first started to work at Chipotle, I enjoyed the pay and the free food. Things were going fine, until I started to damage my hand by working 14 hour shifts every Saturday and Sunday while working 40+ hours throughout the week. Doing my job became physically impossible. I brought this to management's attention, and they requested a doctors note about my injury. After seeing a doctor and getting written proof of my injury, I was let go less than 3 days after turning it in.

Focus more on customer service, and less on proper "cut sizes" and silly rhymes and poems that tell you how to keep the store clean. I watched my GM hold up an entire line of customers while he held an impromptu meeting about how he didn't get his Restauranteur promotion and how many people he was going to let go because of it. One customer actually get upset and walked back into our area just to get someones attention to make her food.

Don't overwork high school and college students. Too many times I have gotten in trouble for missing a shift or arriving late but when in fact I was in school.

Title: "Great company in general, but needs restoration"
Pros:
Great food
Starting pay is great
Cons:
Poor management
overworked
stressed
not payed enough to deal with above
Advice to Management: Management is not responsive to crew members opinions and shrug them off. Upper management does not care whether or not store is properly staffed with the right amount of managers, due to store not being "clean." Its hard to address the issues that need correction when new apprentice is running 3 jobs and not his or her own job. Upper management needs to not be condescending and be understanding of what is wrong and help fix the problems and not be negative about it. Also, it would be helpful to actually see upper management at my store, have been working there for over 6 months and have never seen them at the store that I work at, just because I work the evening shift does not mean you are not able to talk to your employees and see your store.

Title: "Work work work"
Pros:
Starting pay is usually 8.50 or more.
GREAT break benefits (as much food as you want for free).
Payed breaks.
Can be a very fun job.
Cons:
They are not kind to temporary hires.
For how much work is required, pay seems rather low. There are no pay increases or very little increase.

Title: "Horrible General Manager- corporate hard to deal with"
Pros:
easy to move up
I liked the idea of the company culture- but was never put into practice
Cons:
corporate does not listen
Employee journals are a joke
I worked a ton of overtime (15hrs/week)
General manager did not care about any of her staff
turnover rate very high

Title: "Chipotle is a great company to work for, but as tough!"
Pros: The staff is all very friendly, the possible job advancements are unlimited. I know someone who started as a crew member and is now and IT person who travels around to stores and helps them.
Cons: Chipotle HAS to be your life or you won't last. This really is not cool all of the time. The things that you have to know, you have to know 2 different ways, and well pretty much as many ways as there are managers. You have to know the "Chipotle" way, your way, his way, her way, etc...

Title: "My experience at Chipotle .... Interestingly,,,"
Pros:
The staff is very friendly, advances work possible.
Work area clean, safe environment. It 'a team work, good organization .... The Food and' very good quality, as well as control of food all top notch
Cons:
Advice ....
First ... The staff is trained ... not while working ..
Second ..The pay and 'really low .. and this' work is manual .. but you must enable', velcita, fatigue .. sometimes not 'can not make the break panzo .. difficult even to go to the bathroom or to take a vessel of water ...
The rhythms are formula one .. while the pay and 'truly ridiculous, of course the labor market and' the catastrophe ... but here it borders on the ridiculous really ... very few would take very little to make this work, and so also this company truly classy ....
Advice to Management:
management and 'oriented rapid production of products of good quality ...
The real problem 'time .... and 'always late ....
Not even a Chinese worker of the first millennium starch could be in time with the rhythm required by the company ..
Moral ..
Chipotle and 'a financially solid company, well organized .. to get the most with the least investment ....
Workers are useful but not essential .... lost one coming ten new,,
Meditate people meditate ....

Title: "Terrible Experience to say the least."
Pros: There are a few pros to working at Chipotle, including paid breaks, one free meal on the clock and 50% employee discount off the clock.
Cons:
I'm not trying to bash the company in any way, but this was my personal list of cons working there for one month:
- management lost my application
- management could not set up my direct deposit
- took management forever to get my employee ID number (needed to clock in, as well as to get your pay)
- what little training I was provided was not sufficient
- you are constantly being timed if you are doing prep
- i feel i had biased reviews from managers on my timing (they kept telling me I wasn't working fast enough, when I was working just as fast as my fellow employees and was prepping alongside one of the managers and I was keeping pace with them)
- I was told I was too slow working the line (where your put the food together for customers), yet in my section I had 6-8 customers' orders waiting on the next person's section to do their part so that I could have any room to take more orders.
- the most hours I was scheduled in a week was 20, usually averaging 18ish. and my last week they had me scheduled 11 hours.
Advice to Management:
- Invest in training your employees correctly, it will go a long way.
- Be more organized
- Management needs better training

Title: "Get back to the basics"
Pros: Good people, good food, challenged to deliver my best daily.
Cons: Too focus on dog and pony show to be a restaurenture (still cant spell this made up word after 5 years) and not focused on the basics like ever rising cogs!
Advice to Management: You got to realise that the R visit is the best you see them and it is a downward spiral from their.

Title: "Alot of work."
Pros: There is plenty of room to move up in the company so you just have to work really hard and you will get there.
Cons: It's so busy and they run on a bare minimum staff, its hard to schedule people and to train others. They never taught me how to manage or anything like that no classes nothing. I just wing it.
Advice to Management: Run on a little higher labor percentage and maybe do some sort of management training class.

Title: "Frustrating, stressfull, and unrewarding. That's the Chipotle experience!"
Pros: Almost all of your co-workers will be easy and fun to work with, you can't beat learning how to make great tasting food (even if it isn't authentic) and of course, how could you not love being able to eat what you make.
Cons: Micromanagement is never easy to deal with. Restaurant environments are always fast-paced and and often frantic but it doesn't make it any easier when you work so hard you're sweating profusely all while being what some may consider "harrassed" by low level cronies.
Advice to Management: Order is everything, without it nothing gets accomplished. Morale is equally important. Though money is definitely a motivating factor in maintaining employment, comfort and and confidence in your company's agendas are just as major.

Title: "Very hands-on and interactive interview process."
Pros: Fast paced, upward mobility, potential for more than 40 hours per week. Some locations are seeking or have already achieved "restauraneur" status, making their employees more desirable and can command more pay.
Cons: Extremely high standards and expectations, any work above prep and line work is worth more than the $8/hr base pay most employees start at. Can be very intense during peak hours.

Title: "It's OK to work there until you do more then other managers and your GM"
Pros: People who you work with (not managers) and seeing the regular customers.
Cons: Working every weekend and and when you have to close and not get out until 1am because crew won't move to get stuff done. and then you have to open the next day is real hard.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees the way you want to be treated and help your management staff

Title: "Great benefits and good opportunity for advancement"
Pros: Free meals with every shift, best food you'll ever eat, good opportunity for advancement, starting pay is higher than minimum wage.
Cons: It is a fast paced work enviroment, if you are lazy you will not last long in this company
Advice to Management: Keep doing what your doing, no complaints from me.

Title: "Prettty good"
Pros:
Above minimum wage
Good hours
Good opportunities
Friendly employees
Cons:
More work than what youre payed for
Management not always on top of things
Have to pick up other peoples slack a lot becuase of how much is required from individuals
Advice to Management: Make sure everyone does their job and not have people doing others work for them constantly.

Title: "The company sets you up for success personally and professionally."
Pros: A company that invests into you as much as you invest into it. Being promoted is easy if you put the time into learning everything you need to and remain invested with the company. Managers take a personal interest in ways to help you succeed and its from the ground up. Its rewarding to help people reach their goals within the company as well.
Cons: Same as any counter service Restaurant its a fast paced and sometimes stressful job.
Advice to Management: Keep trying to change the way we think about fast food

Title: "Hard work, sometimes too much. But still great company"
Pros:
*Being a part of a company in which you can grow
*working around healthy food
*most happy customers
*Upper management seems to really care about the business as a whole
*benefits
Cons:
*the work expected of those who work for minimum wage is ridiculous. Especially for students. School always comes first. Sometimes managers don't realize that.
*everything else is great!
Advice to Management: Maybe train your supervisors and managers more to distribute workload evenly and efficiently. Also give them a higher raise when they move up through the company. Because the raise is merely laughable.

Title: "Great Idea and Concept"
Pros: Great environment, fun and fast paced position.
Cons: Management is a joke.. Their turnover rate is discouraging for anyone seeking management positions.
Advice to Management: Stop firing managers all of the time.. it makes for chaos for your workers and stresses out the other managers.. who eventually get worn out and quit or fired.

Title: "Good"
Pros: Decent starting wage of $9.00 a great deal of growth opportunities and good benefits, good locations and opening more this year.
Cons: not many only thing i can say is the hours aren't divided equally, you're either a closer or an opener. obvious favorites
Advice to Management: Treat everyone equally.

Title: "Boys club"
Pros:
Great Food
Great employees...
many opportunities for growth
Many opportunities to have fun throughout the day.
They STRIVE for a great culture.
Company Car
three weeks vacation
low base pay
Cons:
...but fall WAY short; extremely gossipy and backstabbing culture is rampant.
It's a boys club--even though there may be a woman or two.
EVERYBODY has to like you...even people who have never MET you!!!
Always on the verge of being fired.
Had to fire those Great employees because they didn't want to be a manager.
High skill job at low pay for crew
They make you feel like a bad manager; even when you knew you weren't.
extremely OCD about everything being perfect. If you are not perfect all the time...gossip begins.
Minneapolis is becoming a notorious bad market to work for in this company.
Advice to Management:
Stop firing people to keep your job. It's really transparent, don't you think?
stop actively throwing people under the bus.
Don't throw stones in Glass houses.
Realize high volume restaurants are NOT the same as low volume.
Be a leader; not a tattle tail...it makes you look incompetent and unprofessional.

Title: "It was a fast paced stressful work."
Pros: good organizational structure and culture.
Cons: work a lot for a little pay
Advice to Management: work to advance to upper management... be motivated to want to excel to do well in this company

Title: "Fun, easy job"
Pros: easy, straight forward, flexible hours, fun staff, cool to learn about the company, wasn't minimum wage!
Cons: too much pressure to move customers quickly in line but hard to not seem rude when doing so

Title: "Great food, OK policies."
Pros:
-More often than not the people you work with will be motivated and excited about what they're doing.
-Flexible hours for students and requesting time off is normally a simple process.
-Laid-back work environment.
-Paid breaks, and as long as you eat at your Chipotle during that break the food is free, 50% off otherwise.
-Promote from within the crew meaning everyone has the opportunity for advancement given that they put forth the effort.
Cons:
-While the initial hiring process and training (Known as SWAT) for a new store is rigorous those standards seem to drop significantly when it comes to new hires.
-The apprentice and GM at my specific store often leave early, sometimes as much as two hours, when they think things are running smoothly. This can lead to being understaffed during rush which lowers the effectiveness of crew members.
-Communication among the managerial staff is lacking. There are often multiple "correct" ways to perform a task depending on who is on staff any given night. This leads to confusion, especially among new hires.
-Some managers would rather pass blame on to crew members and other managers than take responsibility for their mistakes. This reduces store morale significantly.
-As with any retail/food service position you'll often find that customers are unnecessarily rude or hostile towards you, sometimes it's something that's happened at the store sometimes it's not. The degree of this certainly varies depending upon your area but it's not always a job for the thin-skinned.
Advice to Management:
On the store level:
-Take the same amount of time you dedicate to those you put through SWAT to those you intend to hire later on: You spend three days training people during SWAT and at any given time they can be told not to come back if they aren't up to snuff, where-as six months or a year after opening an interview or two will suffice.

On the corporate level:
-Take time to ensure all of your General Managers and Apprentices are effective at what they do. Having people in those positions that leave early and exhibit an inability to accept responsibility for their incorrect actions sets a poor example for new hires and lower managerial staff.

Title: "There is never enough time..."
Pros: The food at chipotle is great!
Cons: The amount of pressure for a burrito joint is unheard of!
Advice to Management: Have reasonable expectations and goals!

Title: "Fun place to work if you don't care about Benefits."
Pros:
It's a fun place to work.
You have the opportunity to make a career out of a simple job.
And you get to eat great food for free.
Chipotle has the best music.
Cons:
They push you to do too many jobs in so little time.
Most of my co-workers burn themselves on the tortilla press machine and most have scars for life.
They want to break records everyday in transactions made at lunch time and they don't care how bad we the employees push our costumers to order their food.
You don't get any good or benefits at all unless you are Management.
Advice to Management:
Is not all about being "Green" and "Naturally Raised meats" how about providing good benefits for all employees?
And let's not forget your laughable raises. 5cents, 10cents or 15cents if you did really good.
But if you work really hard and get promoted from crew to Kitchen Manager you get another laughable 50cents and if you work again really hard and get promoted to Service Manager you get another 50cents.

Title: "Easy to move up within the company as long as you've got a good manager."
Pros: They give you free food. They promote training employees and moving them up the promotion chain.
Cons: Each store will vary widely on how they treat their employees. If you end up at a bad store, you'll never get promoted.
Advice to Management: Remove the managers that don't encourage growth and promotion. Also, the "all-natural" thing is just a fad. Prepare for a time when people don't equate all-natural with healthy and tasty.

Title: "Sold out for the almighty dollar."
Pros: Fast Paced, Exciting, People LOVE Chipotle and it's nice to be part of that.
Cons:
In the Mid West, Upper Management plays favorites. If you support the personal agenda of management you get the promotions and best assignments. If not, you don't matter to them.
Also be sure not to ask questions, you get labeled a trouble maker and are not a "team player."
Advice to Management:
Stop making your personal pet projects a requirement to being a "team player."
Stop having one set of rules for some and another set for the favorites.
Stop allowing illegal immigrants to work in your stores. Stop looking the other way.
Steve Ells is a puppet held hostage by share holders; he sold his soul and the heart and vision of Chipotle for cash. Chipotle is a shadow of its former self since going public.

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros:
-free food, paid breaks, decent corporate culture
-management typically has to work their way up from crew so they usually know what its to be crew and have insight
Cons: - lots of repetitive tasks to log food safety (good in principle but sometimes really annoying to complete it all in a location where the line literally never stops)

Title: "Very past paced"
Pros: Slightly higher than minimum wage, very flexible hours
Cons: Very very fast paced, never-ending lines
Advice to Management: Be more open

Title: "Light work"
Pros:
Great Co-workers
Fun environment
Awesome personalities
Clean
Cons:
Too many people
Too busy
A little bit of workers
Need more workers

Title: "service Manager"
Pros: you work with people from different cultures and share experiences while you cook
Cons: communication is very bad, you work too much, it is very stressful because of the amount of clients that are received and you do not have additional services
Advice to Management: the communication with the manager is not effective

Title: "cashier"
Pros: good company to work for
Cons: nothing to say about the company
Advice to Management: n/a

Title: "Chipotle Crew Member"
Pros:
-Great team members
-Good experience for prep
Cons:
-Horrible hours
- shifts can be cancelled if store isn't busy
-Amount of work=pay not worth it

Title: "Okay but not for building a career"
Pros:
- you get always paid the right amount, even when you work overtime
- they respect break time and encourage you to take it
- free meals on shift
Cons:
- very corporate culture
- too much work for little money
- too many "motivational" talks - a bit patronising

Title: "Good job for those who are willing to work"
Pros:
-above minimum-wage pay
-free meals each shift
-50% discount any other time
-easy to advance to management roles if you work
Cons:
-it's physically taxing work
-management can get catty
-availability isn't always stuck to
Advice to Management: Take into account when a worker is a student and their age. Sometimes I got hit with 25+ hours when I asked for as little as possible during exams. However, I find that my location did a good job in general of listening to my requests. I know it wasn't the case for other co-workers.

Title: "Good work environment"
Pros: Nice working environment, good possibility of promotion, friendly management
Cons: The salary was a bit low to be in London

Title: "Wonderful crew and amazing opportunity"
Pros: Chipotle offers its employees every chance to grow and advance within the company. My managers were always very flexible and understanding, whether it was in regards to shift changes, emergencies, or having a strenuous shift that left you drained. I worked at two different locations, one in California and one in Texas. My crew members became close friends and my managers (at all managerial levels) fostered strong bonds while maintaining a healthy working relationship.
Cons: I think the worst part was the rude customers. At the Texas location we were right across from a university and from that you sometimes had the rude and entitled college student or adult come in. And at the California location the store was located in a wealthy business and residential area which meant the average customers that came in had a different view of customer service. You learn to perfect your rage smile.
Advice to Management: Be patient with new employees. And stop hiring male back of house when you have perfectly capable women in the front of house who want to advance their skills and learn all areas of the store. I had to fight to get put on Grill for months while they continually hired fresh young guys who would quit after three days training on Grill and Prep.

Title: "Not good place to work"
Pros: Free food and good friend
Cons:
get fired because of ridiculous reasons

Get 50% only at the location work

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: The employee environment was amazing, everyone was very supportive. In addition, the free meal every time I worked as amazing. The 13 Characteristics of a Chipotle employee was a very interesting way to motivate employees.
Cons: Although the supportive environment might be seen to encourage employees, the way it was done sometimes created an extremely competitive environment. It was as if both managers and peers were talking down to you. In fact, I had an awful experience with my managers regarding communication.
Advice to Management: For a company that thinks of themselves as honest and supportive, they should double check and make sure their managers, the people leading the restaurants, actually have those values. I spent half a year being honest with them, while they failed to communicate about time off, or even adjusting my work schedule around my school schedule.

Title: "50 hrs a week job,"
Pros: Competitive pay, good bonus, decent benefits, some opportunities to grow the company has a good culture but in canada we are left behind in a lot of things
Cons: Not too much support from above not too many opportunities to grow, they change your goal every 6 months canada get left behind

Title: "Dish washer"
Pros: Friendly staff and fast pace, it's impossible to get a full routine
Cons: At some point the preassure becomes difficult to handle. But isn't every day.

Title: "Bad management causes high turnover rate"
Pros:
You get to know all positions in the front and back of the house overtime.
They provide high standard training and some knowledge such as food handling is being used everywhere in the food and beverage industry.
Cons:
Management is just ridiculous.
You will be brainwashed and tested overtime on their company value, mission and everything.
If the area manager doesn't like you, you are likely to be ignored when there's manager in training position opened.
Work is very hard and not rewarding. They will tell you that you have a chance to become the next manager in training but will let your hope up and never actually do it. You will be blamed for ridiculous customer complains. As a lot of customers realize that if they complain, they would get free meal and they start abusing it.
A lot of good people who have high potentials but have lost a chance to become a manager or higher have quit in the past year, and now because of lack of staffs in the management team, they have been promoting people who are less qualified than those who left to the management. Shame to say that they are heading to their end.
Advice to Management: Realize how good your people are. Don't disencourage them or give them fake hope just to leave them there to do the job.

Title: "KMIT Training"
Pros: You can get any help you need from your Managers.
Cons: Very low salary what you re doing for.
Advice to Management: Please try to appreciate a good crew member & don't slow down the promotion.

Title: "Grill"
Pros: Free food, paid break, friendly employee , good hours
Cons: Was like joining cult ....over worked ...not worth it for fast food.

Title: "Crew Member"
Pros: Fun to work with lots of people.
Cons: Too much politics internally and lazy airheads.
Advice to Management: Live up to the standards and stop being money hungry.

Title: "Lyrical"
Pros: It was one of the best tikes I've ever had working for such a great store was a wonderful experience.
Cons: It was too much of the same things over which was repetitive and it wasn't very amazing of the things we had to do.
Advice to Management: I would ask them to please overview the various funding options for life insurance policies since they differ very uniquely in various circumstances.

Title: "Great"
Pros: It is a fast paced environment and as you know, very busy! Definitely great team mates, great store manager
Cons: you have to be ready to stand all day. Need to work for weekend shifts so be ready for it.
Advice to Management: empower the employees so that they love the job. Overall, I would say keep up the good management that you are doing.

Title: "cashier"
Pros: Good people to be around. Great, great food.
Cons: Not many down sides in working with the company.
Advice to Management: Allow the new workers to grow into the field. Don't expect too much from inexperienced employees but train them to be better.

Title: "Hardwork but fun"
Pros:
-Free food each shift
-Fun Crew
-Learn new cooking skills
Cons:
-Work Can get VERY repetitive
-labor
Advice to Management: none

Title: "Nice Place to Work"
Pros: The environment is amazing and the people is very nice,
Cons: The work is unbalanced. Some people work very hard and some of them no.

Title: "CAshier"
Pros:
The breaks are paid
They always provide with extra benefits and rewards
They have a really competitive management structure
Cons:
Sometimes the food is salty
Sometimes trash cans are really messed up
Advice to Management: reduce the risk of contamination to a level near zero

Title: "Suck ups welcome!"
Pros: Loved my co-workers, free food, chill vibes. Good workout, good hustle, definitely earned every damn penny. A lot of opportunities to move up the team, but that's where the sucking up to the managers part comes in handy.
Cons: Ridiculous managers every location I've worked at. They will fire you if they don't like you, as to them that's a valid reason for termination. They all gossip about the co-workers at manager meetings, and there is no job security whatsoever.
Advice to Management: Maybe start talking to your employees about what problems you have with them, instead of spreading rumours behind their back. Justin and Amy, this is for you. Pay better attention to your stores!

Title: "This is CANADA"
Pros:
Great people to work with
Fast-paced environment
Lots of skill training
Free burrito/bowl/salad per shift, paid lunch break after 5 hours
Cons:
Management treats people as disposable, hires many young workers on visas who feel they have no other choice and who do not know they are being exploited
Federal, provincial and local laws are not followed
Work is never done fast enough, employees have to cut corners to survive and food safety suffers
Constant employee turnover due to unreasonable management demands eg. employees are expected to find their own replacement if they have to miss a shift for any reason
Inflexible schedules mean employees always work unless they are dead, sick employees have no incentive to stay home
Advice to Management:
Food With Integrity includes treating your employees with respect too.
The laws must be followed. It's not optional because you are a US company.
If you want to contain your food contamination problem, you must solve your labour problem.

Title: "Crew"
Pros: Lots of fun people, and always a job to do. Perfect for someone who loves to be productive and build relationships.
Cons: If you are not someone who loves to be on your feet for most of the day, or if you do not like interacting with other people, this job is not for you. May also be bad if you have a bad crew, but this is very rare.

Title: "Backlashing"
Pros: For Pros I can mention only free food
Cons:
* team - as much as they want to come out friendly no one was friendly to me
* training- I was trained by one of the crew members who was always late for morning shift and never explained me why and how things are done.
* Break- I never was told how long will the break be. Sometimes it was 30 min sometimes 15
* Characteristics- I started to work 2 days before my grandmother passed away which I explained to manager and yet I was blamed that I am not happy enough. It's not possible to always have characteristics. The only thing that comes out of it is fake people.

Title: "Service Manager"
Pros: When you have a great team working with you, everything is smooth and easy even though it is very busy during lunch or dinner. It all about the team work and everyone acting as a top performer. They have a great vision about having a team of top performers who are empowered to achieve high standards.
Cons: When the there is a bunch of new hires and the training wasn't set up that great thing fall apart easily when there is a bad team and bad influences. People talk a lot of stuff but not do a lot of stuff. It depends who is working who has the leadership to guide everyone. It is a hard and heavy job.
Advice to Management: Training is very important and taking care of their own rolls and be fair about scheduling spreading the good people with the whole team but not to make unfair schedule.

Title: "Work at Chipotle"
Pros: Free food, nice crew and good experience
Cons: Hard work for a low salary

Title: "Crew Member Experience"
Pros: No experience required! You just need to have the right attitude and personality to fit in with your team. Working with the team is the best part and you empower each other and create a good work atmosphere. Free food! You get one free meal on the days you work. And you serve quality food to people, you see the process and you learn a lot about all aspects of the job.
Cons: It's always busy, so be prepared to always be doing something. Working really late if you're closing. There's a lot of multitasking, but you get used to it and you have to make sure to build good communication with your team so you know when to ask for help.
Advice to Management: In our store, there seemed to be poor communication between managers. When there were problems with the schedule, the managers blamed it on the other. I'd advise being more transparent with your choices and explaining why something changes. Also, explain opportunities to crew members more clearly.

Title: "Fun"
Pros: It's fun, and good experience working in a fast-paced environment.
Cons: There isn't any cons I can think of right now.

Title: "Tasty Experience"
Pros: Fast paced environment for learning
Cons: Too noisy some times. Sometimes too busy

Title: "Very quickly"
Pros: The enviroment its good and sometimes fun, you learn a lot
Cons: The time is the biggest challenge, and be so quick

Title: "OK experience"
Pros: Worked with great people, paid breaks
Cons: Chipotle culture can be very cult-like at times, constantly pushing their values down your throat when you merely just want to make a paycheck to payoff school (like in my situation)

Title: "good"
Pros:
-TIPS (working part time, I got maybe about $25~30 per month, which isnt alot but its a freebee and it stacks up when you think about it long term. Plus how many fastfood jobs gets tips?)
-The picky interview process means great crew! You have to be nice, and enthusiastic to be hired which means great coworkers which makes the job that much more better and fun.
- Above avg wage, $11 here.
Cons:
- Way too much work, exhausting.
- Very fast paced, you will not do well if you're slow or even average.
-The racial demographics seems to be a bit biased towards a few specific races?
- If you become a GM you will be bombarded with hours, I mean 50+ hours per wk, be warned.

Title: "Great team spirit."
Pros: Team spirit, everyone helps each other.
Cons: Hard work, like any restaurant job.

Title: "Amazing Job"
Pros: Awesome environment, Free Tacos, amazing people
Cons: Stressful lunch rushes, not enough employees
Advice to Management: Keep it up

Title: "Working here has its rewards"
Pros: Chance to move up and excel
Cons: Biweekly pay. Ugly shoes. Small store

Title: "It was a awesome experience"
Pros: Delicious food ,free meals, nice people to work with.
Cons: Too much work for little money , not enough hours,busy always and a lot of angry costumers each day.

Title: "Great environment, hard work."
Pros:
