- The company and it's morals are good.
- The people you work with are great! Everyone gets along like family.
- You can be loud and active (you have to be).
- The food is great.
- Your position in the company is valued.
- You can promote fairly easily (if you're good obviously).
- Overall a great environment to work in (clean kitchen, good music, good co-workers, good food).
Cons:
- Way too much work for basic pay (extremely high standards are asked of you).
- You can be very easily let go if you mess up too much or don't meet their "13 characteristics."
- There is great pressure working here, and you must be a great multi-tasker or learn to be one.
- Overall, very very high expectations that you would have to convince yourself are not ridiculous.
Advice to Management: You should definitely pay your crew members accordingly to their work, or lower the expectations.

Title: "Okay for Pocket money and Better to go to school if you can"
Pros:
Hello, I’m not here to really bash Chipotle.
 The advice I’m giving you is something that I would tell people whom I’m concerned about.

If you want to do ok or better in the income department.
One option is to stay there for some time and get promoted to upper management. They seem to make decent or good money. That a look at their website about salaries of upper management.
Cons:
Chipotle does have its problem ,it is not perfect.
The health coverage for crew members is horrible. It is expensive and it does not cover preexisting
Conditions. So basically the best kind of crew members are people who are being healthy or in decent health, and can move kind of fast. You start off making 1 dollar more than minimum wage . You are supposed to greet all customers, smile all the time, and make small talk (this is what my boss wants).

     I’m not sure if Chipolte really train their managers . I have managers who insulted me and make me feel like I’m a lesser human being . Because I’m older than some of my crew members, I suppose to know how to run the store better (one manger was trying to tell me that).

 Go to school if you can. Get a degree or study something that is desirable in the job market . Work hard while, you are young, So when you are older, you will not have to suffer with low paid , less income, and the problem that comes with having little money.
While talking to people who work there, some people stay there because they basically have little or no option.

I had made dumb mistakes in the past by studying something in college, that basically don't really help me much in the job field . Learn from me. I'm planning to go back and work for my family or something.....
Advice to Management: If you get into management , don’t look down and insult people people of lower ranking than yours. There are other ways to correct and train people!

Title: "It was fun yet no rewarding in management level"
Pros: Free food, great people, and get to learn about Chipotle
Cons: Rude customers, management sucks, and they need to fire lazy employees
Advice to Management: That they need to not pick favorites

Title: "Best job ever!"
Pros: Wonderful atmosphere and awesome culture. Reviewed frequently so you are learning what you are doing good at and what you need to work on.possible to be GM in just a year, GM's have salary, bonuses, and a company car
Cons: I wouldn't call this a con but it may be to some people. They are looking for future managers. So its not some some part time job. You have to be passionate about it. Its not easy but if you love it you will succeed.

Title: "My expecience at Chipotle was very poor."
Pros: Some of the pros of this restaurant, the food is cooked right infront of you so you know what you're getting and the staff have fairly good attitudes. though not all.
Cons: Downsides? Well they are very expensive for a fast food place. The dishes get so piled up out back its ridiculous. the floors are often slippery or sticky from spills.

Title: "A good learning experience, great food and crew, but horrendous management."
Pros: I love the crew, the fast paced environment, dealing with customers, simple menu, great food.
Cons: Terrible, inept condescending managers. The crew is forced to do a wholesale clean up every night after a long shift. Crazy scheduling, lack of respect for crew.
Advice to Management:
1)Increase the pay so you could attract better workers
2) Find a better way to clean through outsourcing or through better managment
3) Fire most of the managers

Title: "Overworked and under paid"
Pros: Great food! It really gives you something to take pride iN!
Cons: You are never good enough, area managers would threaten to fire you at least once a week, you are talked down to, screamed at, hung up on, dont know you will be transferred until the day before, will find ANY reason to fire you just because you dont smile enough :)
Advice to Management: Steve Ells, if you read this, you have a great thing going but the northeast ohio market if falling apart! Let a team get used to each other instead of transferring managers EVERY 2-4 months!!!!!!!!!!!!

Title: "Great place to eat-----but work elsewhere!"
Pros: Pros are that Chipotle really takes interest in the environment. Most everything they use is recycled if possible....from bottles to even left over food which is taken to the local salvation army.... Also though its not the most calorie friendly place you can feel good to know that you work for a fast food place that doesnt sell processed foods!
Cons: Cons my location was inconsiderate of certain limitations i had----though i was hired to be the cash regisiter attendant---i was continously place in physical labor intensive positions despite the physical problems that it posed for me-----Also they trained under multiple people so it can be confusing the appropriate way of doing something when they arent always doing things the same way (and even the correct way) ...
Advice to Management: Be more considerate of whats best for your employees not just whats best for your company

Title: "Unreasonable expectations of new employees; hypocrtical company /stores"
Pros:
Paid lunch break with free lunch
Compliments and appreciation from customers
Fun Co-Workers (not including management)
Cons:
pay too low for work expected
too physically and mentally grueling for an eight hour shift (or more) with no breaks after lunch
they seem to genuinely care about their employees but they do not (they keep a "development journal" w/ you when you start out but can use that against you)
not very patient or considerate when it comes to training a new employee (can get fired if you make a couple of mistakes starting out
burns and small injuries from the fryer or quesadilla press or kitchen tools are common
because there is the potential for advancement for some people, lower management constantly harass crew members to an unreasonable degree, I know some is expected, so that they can impress the GM

Finally, they are hypocritical when it comes to their ethical message and image. (They treat employees like sweat shop workers (threatening to fire you if you're even 5 minutes over a ridiculous time limit on prep) even though they legally must pay them a certain amount and pay them .75 cents above minimum wage to save face. They mix in food that does not meet the criteria they advertise in order to cut costs and serve ingredients they cannot get otherwise, yet they do not make this clear unless you search their website.)
Advice to Management: Take more time to judge new employees and look deeper for the source of performance problems within the store. Divide morning prep jobs a little more and compliment employees to encourage performance at times; don't just use copious amounts of criticism to improve performance because it may simply discourage new and old employees.

Title: "Unreasonably Unsatisfying."
Pros: You actually have something to do while you're at work, for the whole time you're there. You never have down time, which is good.
Cons: Employees that have been there for a while let you know they've been there for a while. They make you believe they have superiority and let you know when you do something wrong...multiple times. And they do it in the worst way possible. I guess you could say the FOH employees are unprofessional.
Advice to Management: Don't pay attention to how the employee is reacting with others have a harsh word was said. Have a 30 day period of deciding if they're right for the business or not, not 14 days.

Title: "Life-changing and lots of opportunity for someone single, hard-working and smart"
Pros:
-Amazing food philosophy
-Lots of fun (when you have enough people)
-Promotes from within
-Everything is pretty much figured out for you as far as admin duties, you just need to follow them
-Company is growing so fast there are so many open positions
-VEGAS conference!
Cons:
-60+ hours a week if you are lucky, and when you are home it is still not over
-No work/life balance unless you are a crew member
-Minimal feedback and seldom praise once you are salary
-No training or solid structure for running your own restaurant, you basically "learn as you go"
-Many changes to procedures for flighty reasons which is labeled "empowerment"
-Path of communication from upper to lower management is foggy
-Big push for "Restaurateur" but no help to get there with removing low performers and recruiting the right people--just a lot of concentration on minute details that are not the concern yet
Advice to Management: Upper management please spend more time talking to your GMs and teams. Seriously, just call your GMs and ask exactly what they need, they will know -- then help! Prioritize and simplify. Don't allow them to do the job of everyone in the restaurant, instead train them to be a better leader. Make sure your top performers are inspired or they will lose hope and walk away.

Title: "Effective Communication is a Must"
Pros: Chipotle is a lively place to work. Flexible work schedules and understanding managers make coming to work every day a joy .
Cons: A lack of effective communication definitely exists, particularly in getting corporate messages appropriately through the regional level and on location.
Advice to Management: Messages from corporate to all employees can be quite beneficial. Lower level managers should not be an employees sole provider of the company mission, vission and goals.
